GUE_NGL highlights the contradiction between the issue’s coercive measures and their principle that security must not erode fundamental freedoms.  
GUE_NGL underscores the undemocratic nature of advancing these texts while the Council absents itself from parliamentary scrutiny.

resolution: The European Parliament raised objections to the proposed Council text amending the Europol Decision, rejecting it due to the imminent entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, which would establish a new legal framework for police cooperation. It argued that amendments to Europol’s implementing measures should be deferred until the Lisbon Treaty’s provisions take effect, ensuring alignment with the updated governance structure. The resolution called on the Council to withdraw its current proposal and urged the Commission or Council to present a revised Europol decision within six months of the Lisbon Treaty’s implementation, reflecting the reformed legal basis. Parliament emphasized its continued support for Europol’s mission but stressed the need for coherence with the forthcoming treaty framework, instructing its President to communicate this position to the Council and Commission.

title: Creation of an immigration liaison officers network: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 377/2004 on the creation of an immigration liaison officers network
background: Following the 2004 establishment of an EU immigration liaison officers network and subsequent creation of Frontex to coordinate border management, operational synergies between these entities remained unaddressed. The Parliament will discuss amending the 2004 regulation to improve cooperation mechanisms and information-sharing frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally upholds the integration of immigration liaison officers with Frontex operations, perfectly aligning with its commitment to robust border management and cross-border operational synergy.  
EPP applauds the issue’s emphasis on leveraging ICONet for secure data coordination, advancing its priority of technologically enhanced migration flow governance.  
EPP recognizes the network’s critical role in balancing legal immigration pathways and combating irregular flows, reflecting its dual approach to humane yet orderly migration systems.  
EPP commends the rapporteur’s excellence in achieving first-reading consensus, underscoring its institutional dedication to efficient justice and home affairs policymaking.  
EPP emphasizes the issue’s treaty compliance as a model for future initiatives, reinforcing its principle-driven stance on EU legislative coherence.

The proposal overlooks critical vulnerabilities where Member States naturalize undocumented migrants, creating systemic loopholes that the network cannot address.  
EFD condemns the issue's failure to prevent wage suppression and displacement of domestic workers, exemplified by undercutting practices enabled through unrestricted intra-EU movement.

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the integration of human rights monitoring mandates in Articles 4-6, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to refugee protections and ethical migration governance.  
GREEN_EFA approves the strengthened role for Parliament in overseeing liaison officers’ activities, effectively advancing their priority of transparent, democratically accountable border management post-Lisbon Treaty.  
GREEN_EFA welcomes the rapporteur’s inclusion of explicit human rights safeguards for returnees, which rectifies the Commission’s initial oversight in the 2009 proposal.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Article 8 to require biannual public reports on host countries’ asylum conditions, ensuring continuous alignment with humanitarian principles.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that immigration liaison officers must prioritize rights-based assessments over enforcement metrics, urging Council to adopt complementary training protocols.

ALDE strongly endorses the integration of human rights into immigration policy frameworks, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to humane governance and fundamental freedoms.  
ALDE approves the enhanced operational cooperation between immigration liaison officers and Frontex, recognizing this synergy as vital for improving border management efficiency and interagency accountability.  
ALDE endorses the development of advanced operational know-how within the network, crucial for addressing current and future migration challenges while maintaining procedural safeguards.  
ALDE proposes amending Article 4 to mandate annual human rights training for liaison officers, further solidifying ethical standards in immigration processes.

SD completely upholds the enhanced transparency provisions, which align perfectly with SD’s commitment to accountable governance and parliamentary oversight of immigration liaison officers’ cross-border activities.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on integrating human rights safeguards into ILOs’ missions, ensuring asylum seekers’ protections remain central to EU external migration policies.  
SD applauds the negotiated compromise on terminology disputes, recognizing it as a critical step toward harmonizing operational clarity with fundamental rights imperatives.  
SD highlights the rapporteur’s inclusive consultation process as exemplary procedural rigor, reinforcing SD’s prioritization of collaborative interinstitutional lawmaking under Lisbon Treaty frameworks.  
SD unequivocally supports the issue’s unamended adoption, affirming its consistency with SD’s manifesto goals on migration justice and transnational accountability.

GUE_NGL fully challenges the repressive border control focus as incompatible with their principles of humane migration governance.

GUE_NGL highlights the proposal's inconsistency with treaty obligations to protect migrant rights under Article 79(2)(c) TFEU.  
GUE_NGL condemns the prioritization of Frontex/Schengen mechanisms over regularization pathways as perpetuating systemic exclusion.  
GUE_NGL asserts the Council compromise entrenches "illegal immigrant" stigmatization despite treaty-level recognition of irregular status.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning justice and home affairs, adopting its first reading stance as outlined in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs report (A7-0342/2010). The resolution emphasized alignment with relevant treaty provisions, including Article 79(2)(c) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which pertains to immigration policy, and Article 74 on ensuring cooperation in internal security. It urged the European Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or replacing the original text (COM(2009)0322), ensuring procedural continuity under the Treaty of Lisbon. The Parliament instructed its President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing interinstitutional accountability and adherence to legislative processes under the Treaties.

title: Motion for a resolution - Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA): JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the transparency and state of play of the ACTA negotiations
background: Confidential multilateral ACTA negotiations commenced in 2008 among EU and OECD states, raising concerns over transparency and legal alignment with EU data protection and intellectual property frameworks following the Lisbon Treaty's 2009 institutional reforms. The Parliament will discuss ACTA negotiation processes' compliance with EU transparency standards and legal obligations under international trade agreements.

EPP approves the insistence on fundamental rights safeguards, effectively advancing EPP’s priority of balancing IP enforcement with privacy protections as seen in the rejection of warrantless device searches and “three-strikes” policies incompatible with the EU Charter.  
EPP proposes enhancing multilateral engagement by urging the Commission to formally invite emerging economies like China to future negotiation rounds, strengthening the agreement’s global impact against counterfeiting.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity of immediate impact assessments on e-commerce and data protection frameworks, matching EPP’s 2023 manifesto focus on health security and economic competitiveness.  
EPP welcomes the alignment with *acquis communautaire* while suggesting clearer procedural timelines for document access to ensure parliamentary scrutiny without undermining negotiation efficiency.

GREEN_EFA totally endorses the issue's demand for immediate transparency in ACTA negotiations, perfectly aligning with their foundational principle that democratic legitimacy requires open access to treaty documents as enshrined in Regulation 1049/2001.  

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's insistence on fundamental rights protections, particularly its rejection of warrantless device searches and "three-strikes" policies that violate Articles 7-8 of the EU Charter, echoing their decades-long advocacy for digital civil liberties.  

GREEN_EFA totally endorses the call for rigorous impact assessments on ACTA's compatibility with data protection frameworks like Directive 2002/58/EC, seeing this as critical to safeguarding citizens' privacy against disproportionate corporate interests.  

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with leveraging the Lisbon Treaty's Article 218 obligations to assert parliamentary oversight, viewing the issue's legal base requirements as essential to ending opaque "back-room politics" condemned in the debate.  

GREEN_EFA totally endorses reserving CJEU litigation to enforce institutional prerogatives, recognizing this as a necessary escalation to uphold democratic accountability when negotiating processes bypass elected representatives.

ALDE totally endorses the issue's demand for immediate transparency in ACTA negotiations, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to democratic oversight and public accountability as emphasized by Sophia in 't Veld's call for unrestricted document access.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue's rejection of warrantless device searches and 'three-strikes' policies, advancing ALDE's priority to protect fundamental digital rights as highlighted by Alexander Alvaro's concerns about privacy violations.  
ALDE fully supports requiring an impact assessment on data protection and e-commerce frameworks, effectively advancing ALDE's legislative priorities under Directives 2002/58/EC and 2000/31/EC as raised in parliamentary debate.  
ALDE endorses the issue's insistence on maintaining the *acquis communautaire*, perfectly reflecting Michael Theurer's emphasis on subsidiarity and preventing treaty misuse against individual freedoms.  
ALDE strongly affirms the right to pursue legal action through CJEU if prerogatives are undermined, aligning with ALDE's longstanding defense of institutional parity post-Lisbon Treaty as discussed across all interventions.

SD totally approves the issue’s insistence on absolute transparency in ACTA negotiations, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to democratic accountability under the Lisbon Treaty.  
SD perfectly aligns with the demand to reject “three-strikes” policies and unwarranted device searches, reinforcing SD’s foundational stance on privacy rights under Articles 7-8 of the EU Charter.  
SD totally approves the call for immediate impact assessments on fundamental rights and data protection, advancing SD’s priority to safeguard digital freedoms enshrined in Directive 2002/58/EC.  
SD strongly supports the issue’s red lines against altering the *acquis communautaire*, echoing SD’s legislative redlines on IPR harmonization and intermediary liability protections.  
SD applauds the issue’s linkage of ACTA compliance with e-commerce safeguards under Directive 2000/31/EC, mirroring SD’s 2020 manifesto pledge for balanced digital governance.

ECR strongly approves the issue’s transparency demands, aligning perfectly with their commitment to accountable governance under Lisbon Treaty obligations and reinforcing Parliament’s oversight role.  
ECR applauds the rejection of “three-strikes” policies and software patent imports, effectively advancing their defense of digital freedoms and alignment with EU acquis communautaire.  
ECR endorses rigorous impact assessments on fundamental rights, proposing enhanced evaluation of ACTA’s effectiveness absent key signatories like Russia and China to strengthen global enforcement.  
ECR urges proactive disclosure of negotiation texts, fully backing Parliament’s call to end confidentiality while maintaining strong IP protection as a core policy priority.  
ECR emphasizes strict adherence to data protection safeguards under Directive 2002/58/EC, ensuring border measures respect privacy rights enshrined in Articles 7-8 of the EU Charter.

GUE_NGL strongly accepts the issue’s demand for full transparency in ACTA negotiations, aligning perfectly with GUE_NGL’s longstanding commitment to democratic scrutiny and public accountability in international agreements affecting fundamental rights.  
GUE_NGL proposes strengthening the transparency mandate by requiring immediate publication of all negotiation texts to prevent corporate interests from overriding public access to medicines and digital freedoms.  
GUE_NGL approves the issue’s rejection of warrantless device searches and “three-strikes” policies, which effectively advance GUE_NGL’s priority to safeguard privacy rights under Articles 7-8 of the EU Charter.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the urgency of the issue’s impact assessment to expose ACTA’s threats to health equity, particularly regarding generic medicines, in line with their opposition to profit-driven IPR expansion.  
GUE_NGL urges explicit inclusion of parliamentary oversight mechanisms in future negotiation rounds to ensure compliance with Lisbon Treaty obligations, transforming secrecy into participatory democracy.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the lack of transparency and legal clarity in the Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) negotiations, emphasizing the obligation under the Lisbon Treaty (in force since December 2009) for the Commission to fully inform Parliament at all stages. It criticized the absence of a prior legal base, parliamentary approval for the mandate, and public access to negotiation texts, urging the Commission and Council to disclose documents in line with EU transparency rules and Regulation 1049/2001. Parliament demanded proactive efforts to end confidentiality in negotiations, including placing transparency on the agenda of the April 2010 New Zealand round, and insisted on an immediate impact assessment of ACTA’s implications for fundamental rights, data protection (notably under Directive 2002/58/EC and the EU Charter), e-commerce (Directive 2000/31/EC), and ongoing IPR harmonization. It stressed that ACTA must align with the *acquis communautaire*, opposing warrantless searches of personal devices at borders and rejecting "three-strikes" internet policies, as incompatible with privacy (Articles 7-8 EU Charter) and Parliament’s prior amendments. While welcoming Commission assurances that ACTA would not alter substantive IP law, Parliament reserved the right to pursue legal action, including before the CJEU, to safeguard its prerogatives if not adequately informed.

title: Freezing and confiscation of proceeds of crime: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the freezing and confiscation of proceeds of crime in the European Union
background: Persistent challenges in effectively recovering criminal proceeds across the EU, driven by cross-border organized crime activities and disparities in national asset confiscation frameworks, highlighted systemic inefficiencies. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing measures to enhance freezing and confiscation of illicit gains, addressing legal gaps and improving transnational cooperation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the directive's framework for cross-border asset freezing and confiscation as critical to dismantling transnational criminal networks.  
EPP approves harmonizing minimum standards across Member States to prevent criminals from exploiting legal loopholes between jurisdictions.  
EPP proposes enhancing Article 4 to explore civil confiscation models in future revisions, noting their effectiveness in certain national systems.  
EPP emphasizes redirecting confiscated assets to public welfare programs as aligned with its justice-and-solidarity principles.  
EPP applauds mutual recognition provisions for seizure orders as advancing Eurojust/Europol cooperation priorities.

EFD supports the directive’s framework for combating organized crime through extended confiscation measures, aligning with strategic priorities to disrupt criminal networks.  
EFD advises amending Article 5 to require a prior criminal conviction for asset confiscation, ensuring compliance with the presumption of innocence as enshrined in national constitutions like the UK Bill of Rights.  
EFD proposes establishing an EU-level monitoring mechanism under Article 7 to audit national implementations and prevent political misuse, citing documented irregularities in Bulgaria’s application of similar laws.  
EFD highlights the necessity of parallel reforms to border security policies, arguing that unchecked movement of criminals undermines the directive’s effectiveness in reducing cross-border crime.  
EFD urges explicit safeguards in Recital 12 to exempt member states where non-conviction-based confiscation violates constitutional protections, preserving national legal traditions.

GREEN_EFA absolutely accepts the directive's strengthened procedural safeguards that now guarantee fundamental rights protections against wrongful asset seizures.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's EU-level approach to combat organized crime's economic power, which drains resources from social and employment priorities.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the commitment to repurpose confiscated mafia assets as a vital tool to restore public trust in institutions and reinforce the rule of law.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the critical opportunity to operationalize voluntary mechanisms for redirecting illicit wealth into community-focused social programs.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the issue's coherence with their decade-long advocacy for systemic asset confiscation frameworks that deprive criminal networks of operational capital.

SD strongly agrees the directive's establishment of common minimum standards for freezing and confiscating criminal proceeds, aligning with their commitment to combat organized crime by targeting illicit assets.  
SD approves the inclusion of provisions allowing member states to use confiscated assets for social purposes, noting successful precedents in Italy and Ireland as models for EU-wide implementation.  
SD proposes that the Commission prioritize studying confiscation without final conviction in cases of defendant death where illicit origin is evident, urging rapid presentation of findings during the Italian Presidency.  
SD emphasizes the necessity for robust judicial oversight in all confiscation measures to safeguard defense rights, ensuring decisions remain under court authority as highlighted in cross-border cooperation.  
SD advocates for enhanced mutual recognition of freezing orders across member states to address asset concealment in transnational crime, reinforcing trust in EU judicial cooperation frameworks.

ECR partly accepts the directive’s aim to deprive criminals of illicit gains but demands amendments to mandate judicial oversight for all confiscations, addressing risks of abuse in states with weak rule of law.  
ECR supports expanded asset seizure targeting third-party transfers but insists on transparency safeguards to prevent political exploitation.  
ECR requests revisions to enforce unimpeded cross-border agency operations, condemning member state obstructions like the blocked National Crime Agency in Northern Ireland.  
ECR advocates redirecting confiscated assets to social programs for crime-affected communities, aligning with restorative justice principles.  
ECR highlights the need for explicit victim compensation clauses in Article 4 to ensure full restitution over state appropriation.

GUE_NGL strongly promotes the directive's focus on disrupting criminal profitability, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to social justice and wealth equality.  
GUE_NGL approves the issue's advancement of unified EU asset verification mechanisms, which would standardize anti-corruption efforts across member states.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending Article 4 to explicitly require taxpayers to prove the legal origin of disproportionate assets, enhancing confiscation effectiveness.  
GUE_NGL applauds provisions allowing asset freezing without prior conviction as critical to preventing crime's financial incentives.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes that the directive effectively advances their priority of ensuring "crime doesn't pay" through robust confiscation frameworks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading based on the Commission’s 2012 proposal (COM(2012)0085) concerning judicial cooperation in criminal matters and police cooperation under Treaty on the Functioning of the EU Articles 82(2) and 83(1), incorporating input from the European Economic and Social Committee, the Fundamental Rights Agency, and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs’ report (A7-0178/2013). The resolution adopted Parliament’s stance, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments, and instructed its President to communicate the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments.

title: Fundamental rights in the European Union (2009) - Effective implementation after the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon: REPORT on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union (2009) – effective implementation after the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon
background: The Treaty of Lisbon's 2009 entry into force legally bound the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, establishing new legal obligations and institutional roles. The European Commission's 2010 strategy emphasized operationalizing the Charter, alongside ongoing EU negotiations to accede to the European Convention on Human Rights. The Parliament will discuss post-Lisbon implementation mechanisms for fundamental rights compliance across EU policies and member states.

stances.stance:
EPP completely approves the issue’s integration of the Charter of Fundamental Rights into enforceable jurisprudence, perfectly aligning with EPP’s commitment to concrete legal frameworks for EU values.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the emphasis on subsidiarity in ethical matters, affirming that Member States retain sovereignty over issues like euthanasia and abortion as outlined in the issue.  
EPP completely approves the issue’s call for rigorous implementation mechanisms, particularly through national courts and EU institutional coordination, advancing EPP’s priority of effective rights enforcement.  
EPP highlights the issue’s balanced approach to anti-discrimination policies, ensuring precise definitions to prevent ideological overreach while protecting fundamental freedoms.  
EPP applauds the issue’s alignment with international human rights frameworks, reinforcing EPP’s longstanding advocacy for coherence between EU actions and global standards.

GREEN_EFA fundamentally sanctions the issue’s emphasis on leveraging the Charter’s binding force to transform foundational values into actionable rights, perfectly aligning with their commitment to judicial enforceability of equality principles.  

GREEN_EFA highlights the Roma rights case as a critical enhancement opportunity, urging future Commission interventions to robustly apply Article 21 of the Charter against discrimination alongside free movement rules.  

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the proposed early-warning system for rights violations, advocating its swift adoption to suspend contested measures during accelerated judicial review processes.  

GREEN_EFA emphasizes the need to institutionalize a UN-style Universal Periodic Review mechanism, reinforcing the issue’s call for proactive rights monitoring across EU policies.  

GREEN_EFA stresses that coherence in external agreements requires parliamentary oversight of readmission committees, aligning with the issue’s accountability mandates for EU institutions.

ALDE fundamentally endorses the issue’s emphasis on the legally binding Charter of Fundamental Rights, perfectly aligning with the party’s commitment to enforceable human rights frameworks and judicial accountability across EU institutions.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the call for a Commission-led freezing mechanism on contested national policies, recognizing its critical role in preventing human rights violations before legal enactment.  
ALDE fully supports the imperative to systematically monitor Member States’ compliance, including explicit “naming and shaming” procedures, as essential to maintaining EU credibility in global human rights advocacy.  
ALDE endorses the integration of minority protections, LGBT+ rights, and press freedom into fundamental rights reporting, advancing the party’s vision of inclusive, discrimination-free societies.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s alignment with international human rights standards, reinforcing the necessity of coherence between EU actions and UN/Council of Europe conventions.

SD fundamentally advocates the issue’s elevation of the European External Action Service as a global promoter of fundamental rights, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to advancing human rights diplomacy beyond EU borders.  
SD perfectly aligns with the report’s emphasis on the European Citizens’ Initiative, recognizing it as a transformative tool to empower citizens in shaping EU legislation post-Lisbon.  
SD fundamentally advocates the issue’s demand for rigorous Commission oversight of Member States’ adherence to the Charter, particularly in combating media censorship and safeguarding pension rights, reflecting SD’s unwavering stance on rule-of-law enforcement.  
SD perfectly aligns with the prioritization of child protection frameworks and disability rights strategies, underscoring SD’s manifesto-driven focus on eradicating exploitation and ensuring social inclusion.  
SD fundamentally advocates the issue’s condemnation of discriminatory opt-outs from the Charter, emphasizing that equal rights for Polish citizens align with SD’s core principle of universal dignity.

ECR rejects the issue's framework for fundamental rights enforcement as conflicting with subsidiarity principles.  
ECR opposes any Charter interpretation enabling EU competence expansion into national criminal justice systems.  
ECR fundamentally disputes the issue's coherence approach, citing irreconcilable differences between EU and ECHR judicial architectures.  
ECR condemns potential politicization of rights protection through Charter-based EU court overreach.  
ECR asserts the issue dangerously overlooks Article 51's limits on EU jurisdiction over life protection matters.

GUE/NGL supports the issue's binding Charter framework but advises amending Article 2 to explicitly affirm equal legal enforceability of economic and social rights alongside civil liberties.  
GUE/NGL endorses FRA accountability measures while proposing Article 6 revisions requiring automatic infringement proceedings for systemic violations, particularly targeting anti-Roma discrimination.  
GUE/NGL welcomes gender equality commitments but recommends inserting binding wage transparency directives to eliminate the 18% pay gap by 2025, aligned with ILO Convention 100.  
GUE/NGL expresses concern through proposed Paragraph 14 amendments conditioning EU external agreements on partners’ compliance with human rights treaties, citing Libya’s migration abuses.  
GUE/NGL affirms universal rights principles but urges explicit guarantees for undocumented migrants’ access to education and healthcare in Charter implementation guidelines.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the legally binding nature of the Charter of Fundamental Rights following the Treaty of Lisbon, which transformed the EU’s foundational values into concrete, enforceable rights and inspired jurisprudence in European courts. It highlighted the Commission’s annual reporting on Charter implementation and stressed that the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA) must integrate the promotion and enforcement of Charter-based rights into its annual reports. The resolution underscored the EU’s obligation to align its actions with international human rights frameworks, including Council of Europe and UN conventions, and emphasized the Charter’s role in ensuring accountability and coherence in fundamental rights policies across EU institutions and member states.

title: Fundamental rights in the European Union (2012): REPORT on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union (2012)
background: Persistent disparities in social protections, labor rights, and gender equality across EU member states, exacerbated by post-2008 austerity measures, raised concerns over compliance with EU treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The Parliament will discuss challenges to upholding fundamental rights within EU legal frameworks amid economic and social policy tensions.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue's inclusion of drug liberalization and euthanasia provisions, which conflict with Christian democratic values on human dignity and the sanctity of life.  
EPP opposes the proposed Copenhagen monitoring mechanism as duplicative of existing EU justice frameworks and risking politicization of fundamental rights enforcement.  
EPP fully condemns with attempts to reinterpret the Charter of Fundamental Rights to mandate abortion access, asserting this violates subsidiarity principles and member states' constitutional traditions.  
EPP condemns the issue's alleged ideological bias in selectively targeting certain member states while ignoring systemic rights violations against historical minorities in newer EU countries.  
 While some EPP members endorse minority protection mechanisms, the group collectively rejects the issue's approach as undermining national sovereignty through expanded Commission powers.

EFD rejects the issue’s migration principles in paragraph 42, advocating instead for repatriation agreements as the primary tool against illegal immigration, conflicting with the EU’s external relations strategy.  
EFD opposes mechanisms to freeze member states’ legislative processes, deeming them disproportionate and beyond Parliament’s jurisdictional authority.  
EFD fundamentally rejects prioritizing protections for Roma communities and suspected terrorists, arguing this discriminates against citizens in access to public housing and social services.  
EFD condemns the issue’s globalist ideology for undermining national sovereignty by equating non-citizens’ rights with those of EU citizens, fostering societal division.  
EFD highlights the issue’s failure to address austerity’s erosion of workers’ rights and social protections, contradicting their demand for crisis-period prioritization of citizens’ welfare.

GREEN_EFA strongly agrees the issue’s emphasis on upholding democratic values and fundamental rights, which aligns perfectly with the party’s longstanding commitment to defending the rule of law and social justice across EU institutions.  
GREEN_EFA approves the call to enforce gender equality through binding pay transparency measures and childcare access reforms, effectively advancing the party’s priority of dismantling structural barriers to women’s economic and political participation.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the condemnation of austerity-driven cuts to healthcare and social services, proposing to enhance monitoring through the Copenhagen Commission as a neutral mechanism to safeguard vulnerable populations.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the demand to ratify the Istanbul Convention and combat labor exploitation, matching the party’s manifesto goals to eradicate gender-based violence and protect migrant workers’ dignity.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the need to accelerate horizontal anti-discrimination legislation, urging the Council to lift its blockade without delay to ensure full alignment with Charter obligations.

ALDE strongly endorses the issue's emphasis on uniform enforcement of fundamental rights across all Member States, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to ending double standards in EU rule-of-law oversight.  
ALDE approves the call for an EU-wide monitoring mechanism to replace the politically asymmetric scrutiny applied solely to Romania and Bulgaria, proposing to enhance Article 267 TFEU applications by mandating regular compliance reviews for all states.  
ALDE endorses the condemnation of Hungary's media censorship and judicial interference as critical examples justifying the issue's demand for binding sanctions against systemic rights violations.  
ALDE advocates extending the issue's anti-discrimination measures to explicitly require annual audits of Member States' adherence to Copenhagen Criteria, reinforcing the Charter's primacy over national laws.  
ALDE highlights the urgency to operationalize the issue's gender equality goals by linking quota-based reforms to Article 23 of the Charter, ensuring parity in decision-making roles aligns with ALDE's 2011 Women’s Rights Strategy.

SD strongly accepts the issue’s emphasis on enforcing the Charter of Fundamental Rights and combating discrimination, aligning perfectly with S&D’s commitment to equality, social justice, and robust legal frameworks.  
SD approves the condemnation of austerity’s disproportionate impact on vulnerable groups and the demand to extend unemployment benefit portability, advancing critical social protections under Regulation 883/2004.  
SD applauds the call to revise Directive 2006/54/EC for equal pay enforcement and childcare access improvements, directly advancing S&D’s gender equality priorities.  
SD proposes strengthening anti-discrimination legislation by ending the Council’s five-year blockade of horizontal directives, ensuring swift implementation of Parliament’s mandates.  
SD emphasizes accelerating ratification of the Istanbul Convention and finalizing the EU data protection package pre-elections, addressing systemic rights violations highlighted by recent surveillance scandals.

ECR rejects the inclusion of terrorism suspects as vulnerable groups, arguing it dilutes focus on poverty affecting majority populations.  
ECR opposes the issue's approach to minority protections, citing failures to address systemic poverty among majority communities.  
ECR entirely disputes with the issue's push for the Istanbul Convention, highlighting low ratification rates and institutional shortcomings.  
ECR challenges the prioritization of anti-discrimination measures over national sovereignty in social policy implementation.  
ECR disputes the issue's equality framework, advocating instead for a charter of citizen duties alongside rights.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the protection of fundamental rights and gender equality within the EU, emphasizing the need to combat discrimination based on nationality, gender, and disability, and to uphold social and labor rights under the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. It stressed the Court of Justice’s role in interpreting the Charter in social and labor disputes, particularly through preliminary references under Article 267 TFEU, and called for stronger enforcement of anti-discrimination legislation, including ending the Council’s blockade of horizontal anti-discrimination laws. The resolution highlighted the disproportionate impact of austerity measures on vulnerable populations, urging reforms to Regulation 883/2004 to extend unemployment benefit portability to six months and condemning austerity-driven cuts to healthcare and social services. It noted the 16.4% gender pay gap in 2010, rising to 22% in some states, and demanded revisions to Directive 2006/54/EC to enforce equal pay, alongside measures to address women’s underrepresentation in decision-making roles through quotas and improved childcare access, citing that 28.3% of women’s part-time work in 2010 stemmed from care shortages. The Parliament called for combating labor exploitation, forced labor, and trafficking, recognizing victims as rights violations, and urged ratification of the Istanbul Convention to address gender-based violence. It also emphasized the economic benefits of labor mobility, citing a 1% GDP increase in EU15 countries (2004–09), and rejected unfounded claims linking free movement to welfare abuse, stressing equal social security rights under Regulation 883/2004. Lastly, it advocated for EU-wide quality frameworks for traineeships and stronger labor inspections to safeguard workers’ health, safety, and dignity.

title: Justice Programme 2014-2020: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing for the period 2014 to 2020 the Justice Programme
background: The European Union’s 2010-2014 Stockholm Programme prioritized judicial cooperation and legal integration, supported by Treaty on the Functioning of the EU provisions. Cross-border legal challenges and disparities in national systems necessitated enhanced mutual trust and harmonized frameworks. The Parliament will discuss establishing a 2014-2020 Justice Programme addressing judicial training, cooperation, and access to justice.

stances.stance:
EPP supports the emphasis on judicial training programs to build a common EU legal culture, particularly endorsing language-specific legal education and comparative law studies for cross-border coherence.  
EPP advocates for enhanced cooperation through initiatives like the European Public Prosecutor's Office and Eurojust modernization, aligning with issue goals for trust-building in civil/criminal matters.  
EPP advises periodic budget reviews to address concerns about reduced funding adequacy while maintaining focus on priority areas like victim protection and anti-discrimination frameworks.  
EPP proposes strengthening alignment with the Stockholm Programme by amending Article 4 to mandate biennial progress reports on judicial access improvements.  
EPP expresses concern about insufficient mechanisms for national minority rights enforcement, urging explicit reference to linguistic minority protections in Section 7(c) of the regulation.

GREEN_EFA supports the Justice Programme's foundational goals of enhancing cross-border judicial cooperation and trust-building between legal systems, crucial for realizing EU citizens' rights in practice.  
GREEN_EFA advises amending Article 4 to require mandatory EU-funded training exchanges for national legal practitioners, ensuring consistent application of consumer protection laws across member states.  
GREEN_EFA proposes increasing the programme’s budgetary allocation by 20% to establish robust monitoring mechanisms for tracking implementation gaps in civil justice norms.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the necessity to integrate transparency protocols in Annex II, mandating public reporting on progress in harmonizing procedural standards.  
GREEN_EFA stresses the importance of expanding multilingual legal education platforms to address complexities in cross-border cases, noting current resource limitations hinder effective cooperation.

ALDE supports the Justice Programme’s emphasis on cross-border judicial training and mutual trust-building, aligning with ALDE’s commitment to harmonizing legal frameworks while respecting national diversity.  
ALDE advises expanding administrative simplification in funding procedures to enhance transparency and accessibility for NGOs, universities, and private entities, ensuring broader participation.  
ALDE highlights the necessity to explicitly integrate support for non-judicial legal staff training into the programme, reinforcing comprehensive justice system interoperability.  
ALDE urges reinforcing long-term funding for initiatives combating violence against women and children, ensuring sustained prioritization within the programme’s scope.  
ALDE expresses concern regarding potential UK non-participation, stressing the importance of inclusive opt-in mechanisms to prevent exclusion of national legal experts from collaborative benefits.

SD supports the expanded program objectives addressing disability rights and anti-racism, aligning with SD's focus on social cohesion through Article 21 of the Charter.  
SD advises amending Article 3 to mandate gender identity protections in all anti-discrimination measures, reflecting amendments proposed during parliamentary debate.  
SD emphasizes enhancing cross-border judicial training programs to address inefficiencies in civil proceedings, proposing concrete benchmarks for case issue timelines.  
SD recommends strengthening transparency mechanisms in fund allocation to ensure equitable access for civil society organizations combating gender-based violence.  
SD highlights the need to reserve 30% of program funds specifically for gender equality initiatives, citing Article 8 TFEU obligations on anti-discrimination.

ECR rejects the Justice Programme's expansion of EU judicial training as completely challengeing with their principle of subsidiarity, citing existing national programs and excessive budget allocation.  
ECR opposes the inclusion of drugs policy in the programme, asserting this violates ECR's commitment to national sovereignty and duplicates existing EU strategies.  
ECR fundamentally disputes the issue's ideological focus on gender equality and anti-homophobia measures, arguing these priorities distort legal cooperation and threaten free speech protections.  
ECR highlights the proposal's failure to address economic barriers to justice access, directly contradicting their emphasis on practical equality over "controversial social engineering."  
ECR condemns the programme's application to candidate states as overlooking documented abuses of judicial cooperation, referencing the Veljko Marić case as evidence of systemic flaws.

GUE_NGL rejects the Justice Programme's failure to prioritize gender equality funding, particularly the absorption of Daphne into broader budgets without guaranteed allocations for combating violence against women.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the equal treatment of corporations and citizens in program access, contradicting their principle of people-first policymaking.  
GUE_NGL condemns the inadequate budget scale (0.1% of EU funds) as incompatible with addressing systemic justice deficits exacerbated by austerity-driven rights erosion.  
GUE_NGL disputes the issue's silence on political corruption prosecutions, echoing concerns about selective judicial independence across member states.  
GUE_NGL challenges the merged program structure for creating funding ambiguities that risk deprioritizing social justice objectives like migrant rights protections.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0759) concerning judicial cooperation in civil and criminal matters under Articles 81(1)-(2), 82(1), and 84 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, emphasizing the need to align EU legislation with these legal bases. It called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements are introduced, ensuring parliamentary oversight. The resolution further instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural adherence while focusing on harmonizing cross-border legal frameworks and enhancing cooperation in civil justice and law enforcement.

title: Migration from the Schengen Information System (SIS 1+) to the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II) (amendment of Decision 2008/839/JHA): REPORT on the proposal for a Council regulation amending Decision 2008/839/JHA on migration from the Schengen Information System (SIS 1+) to the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II)
background: Prolonged delays in implementing the second-generation Schengen Information System (SIS II), initially planned for 2007, persisted due to technical challenges and repeated testing setbacks. The Commission’s mandate to develop SIS II under Decision 2008/839/JHA faced imminent expiration, risking operational continuity of the existing SIS 1+. The Parliament will discuss amendments to the legal framework governing migration from SIS 1+ to SIS II, addressing delays and institutional mandates.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the prioritization of SIS II implementation under Regulation (EC) No 1987/2006, aligning with their commitment to enhanced cross-border security and integrated EU information systems.  
EPP emphasizes the critical need for rigorous parliamentary scrutiny and budgetary oversight to ensure SIS II’s operational integrity, proposing reinforced transparency in Commission reporting on system testing and migration timelines.  
EPP applauds the issue’s insistence on maintaining SIS II as the primary framework, which effectively advances their strategic goal of modernizing Schengen-area security infrastructure.  
EPP underscores the importance of contingency planning through SIS 1+ RE only as a temporary safeguard, while reaffirming full confidence in SIS II’s long-term technical viability.  
EPP urges strict adherence to Article 293(2) TFEU procedures to preserve institutional balance, aligning with their principle of upholding EU legislative coherence.

EFD supports the migration to SIS II but advises amending Article 2 to explicitly exempt non-Schengen states from compliance obligations, ensuring respect for national sovereignty.  
EFD recommends revising Annex III to mandate an independent audit of SIS II's cost efficiency and technical readiness prior to full operational deployment.  
EFD highlights concerns regarding insufficient external border control integration in the current proposal and urges strengthening real-time surveillance protocols under SIS II.  
EFD suggests incorporating provisions to differentiate asylum alerts from economic migrant patterns within SIS II's database architecture.  
EFD emphasizes the need for strict parliamentary oversight of contingency plans to prevent prolonged reliance on outdated SIS 1+ systems.

GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the issue's emphasis on parliamentary scrutiny and budgetary oversight, aligning perfectly with their commitment to transparent governance in EU security systems.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the prioritization of SIS II implementation under Regulation (EC) No 1987/2006 as effectively advancing robust data protection standards, a core principle in their digital policy agenda.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing accountability by formalizing a sunset clause with strict evaluation criteria to ensure timely project completion, converting contingency planning into actionable governance safeguards.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the call for Commission revisions under Article 293(2) TFEU, urging explicit integration of independent audits to address historical concerns about cost overruns and technical delays.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the need for future-proofing EU IT infrastructure through decentralized solutions, suggesting exploratory measures for multi-agency collaboration to prevent systemic monopolies.

ALDE strongly promotes the issue’s emphasis on parliamentary scrutiny and budgetary prioritization for SIS II, aligning with their commitment to transparent EU governance and operational efficiency in migration management.  
ALDE approves the structured migration plan under Regulation (EC) No 1987/2006, urging Member States to accelerate technical readiness to avoid reliance on SIS 1+ contingency measures.  
ALDE highlights the need to channel allocated funds toward local authorities and integration infrastructure, ensuring SIS II’s data-sharing mechanisms directly support municipalities managing migration flows.  
ALDE proposes amending Article 3 to mandate biannual progress reports to Parliament, enhancing accountability while maintaining full support for SIS II’s implementation timeline.  
ALDE underscores the importance of cross-border societal consensus, advocating for public awareness campaigns to align SIS II’s security objectives with community-level integration efforts.

SD strongly advocates the prioritization of SIS II implementation under Regulation (EC) No 1987/2006, aligning with their commitment to robust EU security infrastructure and parliamentary oversight.  
SD approves maintaining budgetary reserves for SIS II development in the 2011 budget, emphasizing the necessity of financial accountability and continuous scrutiny to ensure project viability.  
SD highlights the need for enhanced inter-institutional collaboration to resolve discrepancies in delegated acts, proposing strengthened dialogue between Parliament and the Commission to prevent procedural delays.  
SD underscores the importance of integrating refugee resettlement coordination with SIS II’s framework, advocating for EU-wide solidarity mechanisms to address humanitarian challenges transparently.  
SD advocates for strict adherence to data protection standards and cost-benefit assessments in SIS II deployment, ensuring compliance with both security objectives and fundamental rights principles.

GUE/NGL opposes fundamentally the migration to SIS II due to unresolved data protection risks and failed technical milestones, contradicting their commitment to safeguarding citizen privacy.  
GUE/NGL rejects the budget allocation for SIS II development, highlighting the squandering of €90 million and demanding alternative solutions consistent with fiscal responsibility.  
GUE/NGL condemns the expanded access for secret services in SIS II, which undermines the separation of police and intelligence agencies, a principle upheld in member states like Germany.  
GUE/NGL disputes the feasibility of SIS II implementation, citing legal and technical evaluations from member states that render the system unachievable and legally precarious.  
GUE/NGL highlights the detrimental social impact of Schengen policies, exemplified by discriminatory border checks eroding public trust in European integration guarantees.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the amended Commission proposal concerning the Schengen Information System (SIS II), while emphasizing its role as co-legislator and budgetary authority to reserve funds allocated for SIS II development in the 2011 budget, ensuring parliamentary scrutiny and oversight. It noted the Council’s treatment of SIS 1+ RE as a contingency plan if SIS II fails but stressed the need to prioritize SIS II’s implementation under Regulation (EC) No 1987/2006. The resolution called on the Commission to revise its proposal in line with Article 293(2) TFEU and urged the Council to notify Parliament of any deviations from the approved text or to consult Parliament again if proposing substantial amendments. It underscored the importance of maintaining transparency and procedural accountability in advancing SIS II, instructing its President to communicate Parliament’s position to the Council and Commission.

title: Migration from the Schengen Information System (SIS 1+) to the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II) (amendment of Regulation (EC) No 1104/2008): REPORT on the proposal for  a Council regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 1104/2008 on migration from the Schengen Information System (SIS 1+) to the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II)
background: Delays in implementing the second-generation Schengen Information System (SIS II) since 2007, technical challenges during testing phases, and the impending expiration of the Commission’s development mandate necessitated legal adjustments. The Parliament will discuss the migration process from SIS 1+ to SIS II, addressing legal framework amendments, budgetary allocations, and project management oversight.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the migration to SIS II as critical for enhancing biometric data verification and cross-border security, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to a secure and technologically advanced Schengen Area.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity of maintaining parliamentary oversight and budgetary control, proposing enhanced transparency in project timelines and testing results to ensure accountability while strongly upholding the issue’s core objectives.  
EPP approves the issue's call for Commission adjustments under Article 293(2) TFEU, effectively advancing their priority of structured migration to prevent delays impacting Schengen expansion.  
EPP highlights the importance of allocating reserved funds for SIS II development, a strategic priority that matches their manifesto commitments to robust EU security infrastructure.  
EPP urges rigorous implementation of the Court of Auditors' oversight role, aligning with their principles of fiscal responsibility and project efficiency in large-scale EU initiatives.

EFD partly supports the SIS II migration proposal but demands amendments to Article 3 to mandate an independent audit of system viability and cost efficiency, reflecting concerns over unresolved financial oversight and untested operational outcomes.  
EFD requests revisions to exclude non-Schengen states like the UK from SIS II obligations under Annex II, aligning with national sovereignty principles and opt-out protocols.  
EFD objects to the issue’s silence on halting Schengen expansion to Bulgaria/Romania until external border controls are rigorously assessed, citing systemic failures in current immigration management.  
EFD urges stricter parliamentary control over SIS II budget allocations in Article 5, requiring quarterly expenditure reports to curb unchecked EU fiscal commitments.  
EFD highlights the proposal’s inconsistency with addressing economic migration drivers, advocating for amended data categories in SIS II to distinguish refugees from economic migrants under Article 7(2).

GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the issue's emphasis on parliamentary scrutiny and budgetary control, aligning perfectly with their commitment to transparent EU governance and data protection oversight.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening Article 3 to explicitly mandate third-party audits of SIS II's data security protocols, converting Tatjana Ždanoka's concerns into enforceable safeguards against misuse.  
GREEN_EFA approves the sunset clause requirement but urges amending Annex II to include quarterly performance metrics, ensuring timely evaluation of cost overruns as highlighted in the debate.  
GREEN_EFA endorses exploring Indrek Tarand's proposal for decentralizing IT development to enhance efficiency, suggesting a pilot program in Tallinn without opposing the core migration framework.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that Commissioner Malmström's oversight must include regular public reports on test results, addressing debate concerns about opaque project management.

ALDE strongly endorses the issue’s budgetary safeguards for SIS II development, aligning perfectly with their commitment to transparent EU governance and rigorous parliamentary oversight of security systems.  
ALDE approves the reinforced scrutiny mechanisms requiring Council transparency, effectively advancing their priority of inter-institutional accountability in critical Schengen reforms.  
ALDE commends the focus on uninterrupted migration timelines as essential for maintaining cross-border security frameworks consistent with their justice policy objectives.  
ALDE proposes specifying fund allocation protocols to ensure 15% of SIS II resources directly support municipal-level technical upgrades, enhancing local operational capacity without opposing the core budgetary structure.  
ALDE completely accepts the issue’s adherence to co-legislator prerogatives, recognizing this as vital for upholding democratic decision-making in EU information system governance.

SD strongly approves the issue’s prioritization of parliamentary oversight and budgetary control, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to institutional accountability. Proposes formalizing quarterly progress reports to Parliament to address concerns about implementation delays while maintaining full support for SIS II’s objectives.  

SD approves the reservation of 2011 funds as a necessary safeguard, urging enhanced transparency in test result disclosures to ensure technical reliability matches the system’s strategic importance.  

SD endorses the call for coordinated refugee resettlement, suggesting the European Asylum Support Office be empowered to standardize national programs and administer a centralized EU resettlement fund, thereby operationalizing solidarity.  

SD emphasizes the critical link between refugee integration and resettlement success, advocating for amendments to earmark 20% of European Refugee Fund allocations for host community preparation and post-arrival support services.  

SD highlights the need for explicit burden-sharing mechanisms within SIS II governance, recommending the issue incorporate mandatory solidarity clauses to alleviate pressure on southern Member States facing disproportionate migration flows.

GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the migration to SIS II due to unresolved data protection risks and biometric overreach, conflicting with their commitment to civil liberties.  
GUE_NGL rejects the technical feasibility of SIS II, citing Germany’s assessment of legal and operational failures as irreconcilable with EU accountability principles.  
GUE_NGL condemns expanded secret service access to SIS II, deeming it incompatible with national legal safeguards like Germany’s separation of police and intelligence agencies.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal’s failure to address systemic profiling of Czech citizens under Schengen, undermining free movement guarantees central to their integration advocacy.  
GUE_NGL demands abandonment of SIS II, citing squandered funds and disproportionate data collection inconsistent with their manifesto against securitization overreach.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the establishment of the second-generation Schengen Information System (SIS II), approving the amended Commission proposal (COM(2009)0508) while asserting its role as co-legislator and budgetary authority. It emphasized the need to reserve funds allocated for SIS II development in the 2011 budget to ensure parliamentary scrutiny and oversight, particularly in response to the Council’s treatment of SIS 1+ RE as a contingency plan. The resolution called on the Commission to adjust its proposal under Article 293(2) TFEU and urged the Council to notify Parliament of any deviations from the approved text or to re-consult Parliament if intending substantial amendments. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to communicate its position to the Council and Commission, reinforcing its commitment to legislative and budgetary control over the SIS II process.

title: Minimum standards on the rights, support and protection of victims of crime: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing minimum standards on the rights, support and protection of victims of crime
background: Disparate national laws on victim protections across EU member states created inconsistencies in rights and support access, exacerbated by cross-border judicial challenges and the Lisbon Treaty's expanded EU competence in justice policies. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing minimum standards for crime victims' rights, support mechanisms, and procedural safeguards within EU criminal proceedings.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the directive's elimination of distinctions between victims across Member States, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to equal justice and pan-European solidarity in safeguarding dignity.  
EPP applauds the enhanced protections for vulnerable groups including children and gender-based violence survivors, effectively advancing EPP's priority of shielding at-risk populations through specialized training for judicial professionals.  
EPP strongly endorses the cross-border enforcement mechanisms and Budapest Roadmap integration, which reinforce citizen trust in EU-wide justice systems while maintaining national implementation flexibility.  
EPP approves the directive’s emphasis on victim-centered legal certainty and trauma-sensitive procedures, reflecting EPP’s principle of institutional accountability to alleviate secondary victimization.  
EPP proposes strengthening Article 9 to explicitly mandate Member State funding for psychological assistance programs, ensuring consistent post-crime support beyond minimum standards.

EFD partially upholds the directive’s intent but requests binding implementation protocols requiring member states to adopt standardized victim protection training for judicial authorities.  
EFD emphasizes the necessity to amend Article 9 to explicitly mandate national funding allocations for victim support services, ensuring practical application of rights.  
EFD highlights inconsistencies with subsidiarity principles, arguing the issue fails to address divergent legal traditions that may hinder uniform victim protection.  
EFD urges revision of Section 3 to include mandatory cross-border mechanisms enforcing victims’ right to avoid perpetrator contact in transnational cases.  
EFD notes the proposal overlooks critical monitoring frameworks, risking uneven enforcement of minimum standards across jurisdictions.

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the directive’s guarantee of rights and protection for all victims regardless of residency status, aligning perfectly with their commitment to migrant justice and universal access to legal safeguards.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the historic inclusion of gender-based violence definitions in EU legislation, effectively advancing their priority of combating systemic discrimination and violence against women.  
GREEN_EFA approves the directive’s recognition of victims’ needs beyond criminal proceedings, particularly for undocumented migrants and hate crime survivors, mirroring their advocacy for intersectional victim support frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA strongly endorses enforcement mechanisms requiring Member State compliance, urging robust budgetary allocations to operationalize protections as outlined in their 2023 justice reform agenda.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening the text by amending Article 9 to mandate EU-wide minimum legal aid standards, ensuring victims can practically exercise their rights without financial barriers.

ALDE strongly advocates the enhanced protections for children in Article 22, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to safeguarding vulnerable populations through Council of Europe standards.  
ALDE applauds the mandatory training provisions in Article 24, which effectively advance ALDE's priority of professionalizing victim support services across all member states.  
ALDE endorses the directive’s emphasis on localized victim support structures and one-stop shop systems, recognizing their critical role in delivering immediate, trauma-informed assistance.  
ALDE approves the measures to eliminate language barriers and financial obstacles for victims, reinforcing their dedication to equitable access to justice within the EU.  
ALDE highlights the directive’s focus on victims of terrorism and gender-based violence as a vital alignment with their manifesto pledge to combat systemic violence through targeted protections.

SD strongly endorses the directive's recognition of gender-based violence against women as a critical step toward equality, aligning perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to combating violence against women.  
SD applauds the mandatory individual victim assessments as effectively advancing SD's priority of personalized justice and preventing discrimination in support access.  
SD fully accepts provisions ensuring practical victim support including multilingual information, legal aid, and compensation, mirroring SD's 2023 manifesto commitments on victim rights.  
SD proposes enhancing Article 22 to encourage Member States to periodically review and expand protections for additional vulnerable groups beyond current minimum standards.  
SD emphasizes the critical need for sustained EU funding through programs like Daphne to operationalize specialist victim services outlined in Article 7, urging Commission commitment to dedicated budgetary lines.

GUE_NGL supports the directive's gender-sensitive provisions, particularly the prioritization of victims facing gender-based violence and mandated access to safe shelters.  
GUE_NGL advises expanding Article 9 to explicitly require member states to fund specialized trauma counseling services for survivors of sexual violence.  
GUE_NGL acknowledges improved legal information rights but proposes amending Recital 21 to mandate multilingual victim assistance frameworks across border regions.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes that while the directive advances victim protections, it should operate within a broader EU action plan eliminating systemic inequalities enabling gender violence.  
GUE_NGL urges periodic review mechanisms in Article 24 to assess implementation gaps in rural areas and marginalized communities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0275) concerning justice and home affairs, emphasizing procedural adherence under Article 294 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU. It formally adopted its stance, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments or alternative texts, and instructed its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments. The resolution integrated consultations with the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions, and joint committee deliberations, reflecting cross-institutional alignment while excluding detailed amendments or voting specifics to focus on finalizing legislative procedures.

title: Motions for resolutions - Improvement needed in the legal framework for access to documents following the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on improvements needed to the legal framework for access to documents following the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, Regulation (EC) No 1049/2001
background: The Lisbon Treaty's December 2009 entry expanded transparency obligations for EU institutions under Regulation 1049/2001, requiring alignment with updated legal bases. The Commission proposed revisions in 2008, with post-Lisbon adjustments communicated in December 2009. The Parliament will discuss improving legal frameworks for public access to EU documents post-treaty implementation.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue's procedural legitimacy, citing violations of agreed intergroup consultation processes and Rules of Procedure compliance concerns.  
EPP fully disapproves extending document access without binding confidentiality safeguards for international agreements like SWIFT, contravening diplomatic necessities.  
EPP condemns the issue's failure to balance transparency with data protection rights and privacy obligations under EU law.  
EPP disputes the legal necessity of overhauling Regulation 1049/2001, asserting the Lisbon Treaty didn't alter Parliament's codecision role sufficiently to justify this initiative.  
EPP warns against unlimited legislative document access during negotiations, arguing this undermines institutional efficiency and third-party trust in sensitive policy areas.

EFD requests revisions to explicitly prohibit any reduction in document accessibility currently guaranteed under Regulation 1049/2001  
EFD slightly approves transparency goals but demands binding sanctions against institutions maintaining "furtive" decision-making processes  
The issue's integration of police cooperation fails to address EFD's concern about insufficient public scrutiny mechanisms in Article 8(2)  
This framework completely disputes with EFD's position that EU secrecy directly enables poorly drafted legislation requiring national implementation  
EFD urges amendment of Clause 14 to mandate real-time publication of all Commission legislative drafts through EUR-Lex

GREEN_EFA supports the issue’s integration of judicial and police cooperation into EU transparency frameworks, reinforcing parliamentary oversight as vital to democratic legitimacy.  
GREEN_EFA advises clarifying Article 42 Charter alignments to explicitly exclude MEPs’ internal communications from public access, addressing misconceptions while preserving scrutiny of legislative processes.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the rejection of reduced access rights, urging binding agreements to expand EUR-Lex coverage of non-legislative documents like international negotiation drafts affecting citizen rights.  
GREEN_EFA proposes accelerating digital platform reforms by mandating real-time document registers, ensuring timely public access ahead of key policy decisions.  
GREEN_EFA stresses aligning fund management transparency with the European Transparency Initiative, requiring disclosure of beneficiary deliberations to prevent corporate lobbying opacity.

ALDE strongly agrees the issue’s alignment with the Lisbon Treaty’s transparency mandates, particularly the extension of document access obligations to all EU bodies, which advances ALDE’s democratic accountability priorities.  
ALDE approves the binding interinstitutional agreements and regular review timelines, emphasizing their potential to standardize legislative visibility across EUR-Lex and other platforms.  
ALDE highlights the necessity of integrating real-time public input mechanisms into the transparency portal to further empower citizen participation in line with Article 15 TFEU.  
ALDE proposes amending the issue to include explicit metrics for evaluating the accessibility of non-legislative documents, ensuring consistent progress tracking.  
ALDE commends the cross-institutional collaboration led by Vice-President Wallis as a critical step toward operationalizing the European Transparency Initiative’s goals.

SD strongly sanctions the issue’s alignment with the Lisbon Treaty’s transparency mandates, particularly Article 15 TFEU, as a cornerstone of democratic engagement matching S&D’s governance principles.  
SD applauds the call to abolish intergovernmental secrecy in judicial cooperation, enhancing parliamentary oversight in line with their 2023 manifesto pledge for accountable EU institutions.  
SD proposes clarifying timelines for interinstitutional agreements to ensure binding transparency frameworks are operationalized before the June 2010 deadline.  
SD emphasizes upgrading EUR-LEX to include non-legislative documents, ensuring consolidated public access as urged in the European Transparency Initiative.  
SD urges expedited Commission-Council negotiations to finalize reforms, addressing delays criticized in the issue while maintaining strict adherence to Article 42 of the Charter.

ECR strongly endorses the issue’s emphasis on transparency as essential to addressing the democratic deficit in EU institutions, aligning perfectly with ECR’s longstanding commitment to accountable governance and citizen oversight.  
ECR approves the integration of judicial and police cooperation into EU transparency frameworks, proposing enhanced disclosure of consultations with external interest groups to further strengthen public scrutiny.  
ECR welcomes the abolition of intergovernmental opacity but urges accelerated timelines for digitizing document registers to ensure real-time access for national parliaments and civil society.  
ECR emphasizes the critical need for full citizen and journalist access to legislative analyses, which effectively advances ECR’s priority of preventing bureaucratic overreach through democratic supervision.  
ECR endorses binding interinstitutional agreements on document accessibility while recommending explicit safeguards against discretionary redactions in non-legislative processes.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need to update Regulation (EC) No 1049/2001 on public access to EU documents following the Lisbon Treaty’s entry into force, emphasizing enhanced transparency as a cornerstone of democratic legitimacy. It stressed that the Treaty’s new legal framework, including Article 15 TFEU and Article 42 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, mandates all EU institutions, bodies, and agencies—not just Parliament, Council, and Commission—to operate openly, ensuring citizens’ right to access documents and participate in democratic processes. The resolution highlighted the abolition of intergovernmental regimes in judicial and police cooperation, integrating these areas into EU law to strengthen parliamentary oversight and public scrutiny. It called for binding interinstitutional agreements by 30 June 2010 to improve document accessibility, including legislative and non-legislative processes, and urged reforms to internal rules, registers, and digital platforms like EUR-LEX to consolidate transparency. The Parliament rejected any attempts to reduce access rights, citing ECJ rulings that link openness to institutional legitimacy, and emphasized the need for transparency in EU fund management and policy implementation, aligning with the European Transparency Initiative. It also demanded clarity in distinguishing public access to documents from internal communications and stressed the importance of timely, comprehensive information for citizens and national parliaments to monitor decision-making. The resolution welcomed the Commission’s December 2009 communication updating the regulation’s legal basis but criticized delays in substantive reforms, urging immediate political dialogue to finalize the updated framework.

title: Information accompanying transfers of funds: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on information accompanying transfers of funds
background: Existing EU anti-money laundering regulations required updates to align with revised international Financial Action Task Force standards and address evolving financial crime risks, including technological advancements enabling complex cross-border transactions. The Parliament will discuss measures to strengthen transparency requirements for fund transfers to prevent illicit financial flows and terrorist financing.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the harmonization of payment definitions and expanded information requirements, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to combating cross-border financial crime while preserving Single Market efficiency.  
EPP approves enhanced transparency in beneficial ownership registries, effectively advancing EPP's priority of eliminating corporate structure abuses through standardized EU-wide disclosure rules.  
EPP emphasizes proportional risk assessment protocols to safeguard legitimate payment system users, proposing minor refinements to online transaction guidelines to prevent overregulation.  
EPP highlights the critical need for international cooperation to pressure third-country jurisdictions lacking transparency standards, urging strengthened mechanisms for cross-border financial intelligence sharing.  
EPP applauds the issue’s alignment with SEPA standards, ensuring traceability without compromising payment system functionality, as outlined in EPP’s 2023 financial integrity agenda.

EFD conditionally agrees the anti-money laundering framework but demands amendments to exempt state-regulated low-risk sectors like Finland's slot machine system from excessive reporting requirements.  
EFD requests revisions to include mandatory EU-level intervention in member states with systemic corruption, citing Bulgaria's failure to prosecute high-level money laundering cases.  
EFD insists the directive must explicitly authorize extended asset confiscation for organized crime proceeds, aligning with Zbigniew Ziobro's emphasis on effective sanctions.  
EFD calls for accelerated implementation of centralized business registries and amendments closing VAT carousel loopholes enabling cross-border fraud.  
EFD warns the current text inadequately balances financial tracking with proportionality, risking overregulation of legitimate entities without addressing core criminal networks.

GREEN_EFA completely sanctions the establishment of a European register of beneficial owners as essential to dismantling financial secrecy structures that enable tax evasion and criminal activity.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on institutional accountability, particularly in addressing past implementation failures through strengthened parliamentary oversight of anti-money laundering frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the societal imperative of reclaiming illicit funds for public services as articulated in the debate, affirming this aligns with their manifesto priorities for economic justice and social welfare.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the focus on transactional transparency to expose hidden ownership chains, noting this advances their decade-long advocacy against offshore tax havens and corporate anonymity.  
GREEN_EFA underscores the moral necessity of linking financial reforms to human progress, framing the issue as a critical step toward democratizing economic governance across Europe.

SD strongly endorses the mandatory public registries for beneficial ownership, aligning perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to dismantling opaque corporate structures and combating financial crime.  
SD proposes amending the beneficial ownership disclosure threshold from 25% to 10% to prevent evasion through layered corporate entities, ensuring stricter transparency.  
SD applauds the issue’s push for EU-wide interconnected registries, effectively advancing SD's priority of seamless cross-border cooperation for law enforcement efficiency.  
SD emphasizes robust whistleblower protections as critical to exposing criminal networks, consistent with SD’s justice and accountability principles.  
SD strongly endorses eliminating exemptions for low-risk gambling sectors, arguing comprehensive coverage is essential to prevent jurisdictional arbitrage by money launderers.

ECR strongly accepts the issue's framework for combating money laundering and terrorist financing through enhanced payer-payee transparency, aligning with their commitment to robust security infrastructure.  
ECR approves the balance between payment system security and citizen privacy rights, emphasizing the necessity to codify strict legal definitions for exceptional data access scenarios in Article 4.  
ECR proposes reinforcing data protection protocols through an amendment specifying that collected financial information may only be retained for 12 months unless judicial authorization is obtained.
