ECR applauds the directive’s operational flexibility to counter evolving criminal methodologies, mirroring their manifesto priorities for adaptive law enforcement tools.  
ECR emphasizes the critical need for proportionality in surveillance measures to maintain public trust in financial systems, urging explicit safeguards against arbitrary data misuse in recital 22.

GUE/NGL slightly sanctions the issue’s anti-money laundering framework but requests revisions to explicitly prohibit data transfers to third countries lacking EU-equivalent privacy safeguards (amend Article 9).  
GUE/NGL highlights the proposal’s failure to address systemic financial deregulation, inconsistent with their stance that unregulated capital flows inherently enable laundering and tax evasion.  
GUE/NGL demands structural amendments targeting tax havens and corporate loopholes, rejecting the issue’s narrow focus on transactional oversight over systemic reform.  
GUE/NGL opposes the omission of a ban on 500-euro banknotes, urging its inclusion as a low-cost measure to disrupt illicit cash flows (revise Annex II).  
GUE/NGL warns that collaboration with third countries must not compromise data sovereignty, citing unresolved conflicts with GDPR principles in Clause 7(b).

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 proposal (COM(2013)0044) concerning EU economic and legal frameworks, grounded in Treaty provisions (Articles 294(2), 294(3), and 114 TFEU). It integrated input from the European Central Bank’s May 2013 opinion and the European Economic and Social Committee’s November 2013 opinion, alongside collaborative analysis by the Committees on Economic and Monetary Affairs and Civil Liberties, Justice, and Home Affairs, with additional input from the Development and Legal Affairs Committees (report A7-0140/2014). The resolution formally adopted the Parliament’s first-reading stance, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts, and directed its President to transmit this position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure procedural continuity and institutional alignment.

title: Internal Security Fund (External borders and visas): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing, as part of the Internal Security Fund, the instrument for financial support for external borders and visa
background: Persistent migration pressures, particularly in Mediterranean regions, and challenges in coordinating border infrastructure and resources among EU Member States prompted the need for enhanced external border management. The Parliament will discuss establishing a financial instrument under the Internal Security Fund to address border security, visa policy coherence, and operational support mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the requirement for EU-added value proof in national programs, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to cohesive European security infrastructure.  
EPP approves merging migration/asylum funds into two instruments but proposes enhancing future budget allocations to match operational realities while maintaining current flexibility.  
EPP completely accepts unannounced project audits and 75-90% co-financing ceilings as critical safeguards for taxpayer funds, reflecting EPP's manifesto priorities on fiscal responsibility.  
EPP strongly sanctions border management funding prioritization, particularly Croatia's enhanced role in Schengen external border protection through coordinated technical assistance.  
EPP recommends streamlining resource allocation under Article 7 to prevent fragmentation risks while preserving multi-actor participation in migration management systems.

GREEN_EFA rejects the allocation of €1.1 billion for 'smart borders' systems, which lack legal basis and contradict their commitment to humane migration management.  
GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the Council's framing of 'fighting illegal migration', arguing it disregards refugee rights and enables border militarization.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the diversion of funds from asylum support and integration programs to security infrastructure, exacerbating humanitarian crises.  
GREEN_EFA demands reallocation of Internal Security Fund resources to prioritize NGO partnerships and refugee protection over surveillance technologies.  
GREEN_EFA highlights systemic contradictions in EU policies that underfund humanitarian corridors while expanding border control mechanisms.

ALDE strongly upholds the issue’s financial solidarity mechanism, aligning perfectly with their commitment to equitable burden-sharing in EU migration management.  
ALDE approves the administrative simplification measures, emphasizing their critical role in accelerating fund accessibility for frontline Member States.  
ALDE highlights the importance of delegated acts to safeguard parliamentary influence, ensuring democratic oversight aligns with their institutional reform priorities.  
ALDE advocates for sustained innovation in cross-border integration projects, reflecting their progressive stance on holistic migration solutions encompassing circular migration pathways.  
ALDE proposes enhancing coordination frameworks for IT systems to mitigate fragmentation risks while maintaining the issue’s operational flexibility.

SD strongly promotes the issue's emphasis on EU-wide solidarity mechanisms, aligning with their commitment to equitable burden-sharing in migration management.  
SD approves the mandatory mid-term review clause as crucial for adapting funding to evolving border security needs while maintaining program continuity.  
SD highlights the importance of maintaining NGO access provisions as vital for safeguarding migrant rights and ensuring operational transparency.  
SD proposes enhancing Article 4(2) to specify minimum percentages for integration funding in national programs, reinforcing social inclusion priorities.  
SD applauds the flexibility provisions for frontline states as effectively advancing their longstanding advocacy for differentiated responsibility in border protection.

ECR conditionally supports the fund’s national program allocations but requests amendments to Article 9 to prevent mandatory cohesion measures that infringe on Member State sovereignty.  
ECR fully againsts with the issue’s systemic coordination requirements, advocating instead for voluntary participation in shared infrastructure projects under Section 4(c).  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of combating human trafficking by not mandating EU-wide harmonized penalties, which ECR stresses as vital in addressing organized crime networks.  
ECR requests revisions to prioritize border security technologies over centralized IT systems in Annex 3, aligning with their emphasis on subsidiarity in operational matters.  
ECR highlights insufficient focus on disrupting migrant smuggling operations, urging explicit funding criteria in Chapter 6 for Member State-led law enforcement initiatives.

GUE_NGL rejects the conflation of migration pressure and asylum requests as a dangerous oversimplification that dehumanizes vulnerable populations.  
GUE_NGL opposes the prioritization of "smart borders" and return measures over integration and asylum funding, which directly contradicts their commitment to solidarity-based migration policies.  
GUE_NGL firmly disputes with the issue’s authorization of EU-funded migration control operations in third countries, viewing this as institutionalizing the Fortress Europe model they have consistently denounced.  
GUE_NGL highlights that the proposal fails to address systemic rights violations by reducing parliamentary oversight and marginalizing NGOs in decision-making processes.  
GUE_NGL condemns the budgetary cuts to community-led actions as inconsistent with their demand for equitable resource allocation prioritizing human dignity over securitization.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about Member States prioritizing national interests in allocating funds under the Instrument, particularly for financing operating support within their national programs, and highlighted risks of fragmentation and duplication due to insufficient coordination in infrastructure, equipment, transport, and IT systems. The resolution adopted the Parliament’s position at first reading, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to the proposal, and instructed its President to forward the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to address these systemic challenges and ensure cohesive implementation of EU policies.

title: Internal Security Fund (Police cooperation, preventing and combating crime and crisis management): REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing, as part of the Internal Security Fund, the instrument for financial support for police cooperation, preventing and combating crime, and crisis management
background: Heightened migration flows, cross-border crime threats, and fragmented EU financial instruments for internal security prompted calls for streamlined funding. Mediterranean states faced disproportionate migration pressures, while transnational crises underscored coordination gaps. The Parliament will discuss establishing a unified Internal Security Fund to enhance police cooperation, combat crime, and improve crisis management mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the enhanced financial oversight mechanisms, particularly unannounced project audits, as aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to taxpayer fund protection.  
EPP approves the 75-90% co-financing flexibility for crisis responses, effectively advancing EPP's priority of rapid EU-level security interventions.  
EPP proposes reinforcing Article 15 to explicitly link migration fund allocations with third-country cooperation agreements, enhancing policy coherence.  
EPP endorses the merged fund structure's operational efficiency gains while suggesting future budgetary expansions to match evolving border protection needs.  
EPP applauds the mandatory EU-added value assessment for projects as mirroring their manifesto pledge for strategic security investments.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue’s prioritization of surveillance and border militarization, which entirely disputes with their commitment to human rights and humanitarian protection.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the allocation of €1.1 billion for “smart borders,” a system lacking legal grounding and exacerbating Fortress Europe policies inconsistent with refugee rights advocacy.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the Internal Security Fund’s focus on “fighting illegal migration,” a framing that overlooks critical aspects of asylum seeker dignity and NGO support central to their platform.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s failure to address integration funding cuts, perpetuating a schizophrenic policy approach that neglects refugee resettlement and humanitarian obligations.  
GREEN_EFA opposes merging security and migration budgets, warning this blurs priorities and diverts resources from vulnerable populations to punitive measures they deem ethically indefensible.

ALDE strongly endorses the issue’s emphasis on financial solidarity for crisis management, aligning with their advocacy for EU-wide burden-sharing in migration challenges.  
ALDE applauds the administrative simplification provisions as critical to accelerating fund accessibility, reflecting their long-standing push for reduced bureaucratic barriers in EU programs.  
ALDE endorses the inclusion of third-country actions, recognizing this as essential for addressing migration root causes—a priority in their cross-border security agenda.  
ALDE highlights the importance of delegated acts to maintain parliamentary oversight, ensuring future flexibility aligns with democratic accountability principles.  
ALDE proposes enhancing innovation clauses by explicitly prioritizing best-practice sharing between member states to maximize project effectiveness.

SD strongly upholds the inclusion of non-governmental organizations in fund accessibility, ensuring civil society’s critical role in migration and asylum initiatives aligns with the issue’s transparency goals.  
SD strongly endorses the enhanced flexibility for intra-program fund transfers, safeguarding timely crisis responses while maintaining minimum allocation safeguards for third-country projects.  
SD applauds the prioritization of solidarity in asylum policy design, particularly for frontline EU states bearing disproportionate migration pressures, as this mirrors their manifesto commitment to equitable burden-sharing.  
SD proposes revising the 2011-era financial thresholds and evaluation timelines to reflect current migration dynamics, ensuring fairer resource distribution for countries like Bulgaria and Italy.  
SD strongly advocates integrating labor market strategies with migration policies to address sectoral employment gaps, leveraging the fund’s structure to advance both economic growth and social inclusion.

ECR conditionally sanctions the crisis management provisions but requests revisions to Article 7 regarding mandatory resettlement quotas, which conflict with national sovereignty over migration policy.  
ECR completely doubts centralized asylum decision-making frameworks in Section 4.2, advocating instead for voluntary intergovernmental cooperation models.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of border control sovereignty by failing to exempt maritime surveillance operations from joint command structures under Chapter 3.  
ECR demands amendment of Paragraph 15 to explicitly prohibit EU-level mandates on national police force deployments, consistent with subsidiarity principles.  
The financial allocation mechanism in Annex B remains inconsistent with ECR's requirement for Member State autonomy in prioritizing anti-trafficking vs cybercrime investments.

GUE_NGL firmly disputes the repressive security focus and migration policy externalization, which entrenches fortress Europe against their internationalist principles.  
GUE_NGL rejects the conflation of asylum seekers with security threats, condemning this issue’s scapegoating of migrants as incompatible with solidarity-based approaches.  
GUE_NGL opposes budget cuts to integration and asylum programs, highlighting the issue’s prioritization of expulsion measures over humanitarian protections.  
GUE_NGL condemns the weakening of parliamentary oversight and community-led initiatives, which centralizes authoritarian border controls they systematically challenge.  
GUE_NGL rejects the "smart borders" funding and securitization logic, viewing it as a betrayal of their anti-surveillance and freedom-of-movement ethos.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal concerning justice and home affairs, adopting its first-reading stance under Articles 82(1), 84, and 87(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It emphasized alignment with opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee (July 2012) and the Committee of the Regions (July 2012), alongside input from its Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Committee on Budgets. The resolution formally endorsed the legislative text, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments, and directed the Parliament’s President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring procedural continuity under EU law.

title: Granting and withdrawing international protection: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on minimum standards on procedures in Member States for granting and withdrawing international protection (recast)
background: Disparities in EU Member States’ asylum procedures, including divergent recognition rates and procedural timelines, alongside a 40% decline in asylum applications in industrialized countries over a decade, prompted calls for harmonization under the Stockholm Programme’s 2012 Common European Asylum System target. The Parliament will discuss revising the 2005 Asylum Procedures Directive to establish uniform EU standards for granting and withdrawing international protection.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the procedural safeguards in Article 23 as absolutely opposeing with their demand for accelerated processing of manifestly unfounded claims.  
EPP opposes the disappearance provisions (Section 4.7) for enabling indefinite procedural delays through refusal of document receipt, contradicting their principle of administrative efficiency.  
EPP condemns the three-application threshold before acceleration as inconsistent with their stance against systematic abuse of asylum channels.  
EPP disputes the six-month evidentiary burden shift (Clause 12b) as creating bureaucratic obstacles to swift refugee status determinations.  
EPP challenges the safe third country exemptions as overlooking critical vulnerabilities in border state systems like Greece's documented asylum backlogs.

EFD totally condemns the directive's EU-wide asylum harmonization as a violation of national sovereignty principles  
EFD rejects the Lisbon Treaty-based procedural consolidation as undemocratic power expansion without public referendum approval  
This conflicts with EFD's position that immigration control must remain exclusively with nation-states rather than supranational bodies  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of Member State autonomy by dismissing their operational objections to centralized asylum criteria  
EFD condemns the issue's alignment with EU "beneficial crisis" exploitation to expand jurisdiction over border policies

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the issue's emphasis on harmonizing first-instance decision quality across Member States, aligning perfectly with their commitment to equitable asylum procedures.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the critical need to address procedural disparities evidenced by 1-65% approval rate gaps between states, framing this as an enhancement opportunity for standardized training of asylum officers.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Article 18 to mandate suspensive effect for all appeals, ensuring no asylum seeker faces removal during review processes without opposing the issue's core structure.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the focus on credibility in protection systems, noting this effectively advances their manifesto goals for dignified refugee reception exemplified by Cyprus and Sweden's proportional intake models.  
GREEN_EFA underscores the imperative to eliminate derogatory narratives about asylum seekers, as raised in debate interventions, urging explicit safeguards against dehumanizing rhetoric in procedural guidelines.

ALDE strongly approves the establishment of a common EU-wide asylum system by 2012, aligning with their commitment to harmonized and equitable protection standards across Member States.  
ALDE proposes amending provisions on safe third countries to establish a unified EU-wide list, eliminating national discrepancies while preserving case-by-case assessments.  
ALDE approves the issue’s emphasis on fair and rapid first-instance procedures, recognizing this as essential to upholding asylum seekers’ rights without procedural delays.  
ALDE applauds the enhanced protections for minors as fully consistent with their advocacy for vulnerable groups in asylum frameworks.  
ALDE emphasizes that framing asylum as a fundamental right rather than discretionary favor aligns perfectly with their human rights principles and treaty obligations.

SD completely sanctions the harmonization of asylum procedures to eliminate disparities between Member States, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to ending the "asylum lottery" through common EU-wide standards.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on front-loaded quality decision-making, recognizing this as essential to upholding international obligations while reducing long-term administrative costs.  
SD completely sanctions the directive’s enhanced protections for vulnerable groups, particularly unaccompanied minors, as a critical advancement of fundamental rights in asylum processes.  
SD unequivocally supports the urgency of adopting fair procedures amid Mediterranean crises, affirming this as vital to transforming Europe from a "fortress" into a zone of principled solidarity.  
SD perfectly aligns with binding burden-sharing mechanisms, viewing coordinated asylum governance as indispensable to addressing North African displacement challenges collectively.

GUE_NGL slightly supports the procedural improvements in Articles 12-14 regarding personal interviews but demands binding guarantees for free legal representation at all appeal stages.  
GUE_NGL requests revising Section IV to eliminate discretionary loopholes allowing Member States to bypass six-month decision deadlines, inconsistent with their principle of swift asylum determinations.  
GUE_NGL completely rejects the issue's failure to standardize reception conditions across borders, contradicting their demand for equal treatment in all procedural aspects.  
GUE_NGL highlights unresolved contradictions in Article 7(3) permitting accelerated procedures without adequate safeguards, risking violation of applicants' rights to thorough examination.  
GUE_NGL requires amendment of Recital 23 to explicitly prohibit detention of vulnerable groups during appeals, aligning with their 2023 manifesto on asylum seeker protections.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the adoption of a codified version of existing legislation on asylum and immigration procedures, confirming that the Commission’s proposal (COM(2009)0554) did not introduce substantive amendments but merely consolidated prior acts without altering their content, as affirmed by the Consultative Working Party of the legal services. The resolution emphasized adherence to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (Article 78(2)) and the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2001 on recasting legal acts, while aligning with Parliament’s 2009 resolution on the Common European Asylum System. It formally adopted its first-reading position, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant future changes, and directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure procedural continuity and transparency.

title: Homophobia and discrimination on grounds of sexual orientation and gender identity: REPORT on the EU Roadmap against homophobia and discrimination on grounds of sexual orientation and gender identity
background: Persistent reports from EU agencies and international bodies documented widespread discrimination, violence, and legal gaps affecting LGBTI individuals across member states, alongside existing EU equality frameworks for other groups. The Parliament will discuss coordinated measures to address homophobia and discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity within EU competencies.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue's approach to family law redefinition as firmly doubting with national sovereignty principles enshrined in EU treaties.  
EPP opposes fundamentally any imposition of gender identity concepts that would require member states to alter constitutional marriage definitions against democratic referendums.  
EPP contends the proposal overlooks critical aspects of subsidiarity by attempting to standardize civil status recognition across jurisdictions through backdoor legal harmonization.  
EPP declares the issue's reproductive rights provisions incompatible with Christian democratic values regarding family structure and child protection frameworks.  
EPP asserts the roadmap creates special legal categories contrary to equality principles by prioritizing specific groups over universal human rights protections.

EFD rejects the issue's push for mutual recognition of same-sex marriages as violating national sovereignty and traditional family definitions.  
EFD opposes "special rights" frameworks for LGBTI individuals, arguing equality must exclude "positive discrimination" that overrides biological realities.  
EFD completely againsts with EU-level gender recognition mandates, asserting such matters belong exclusively to private life and national cultural norms.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of subsidiarity by imposing healthcare/legal recognition standards incompatible with member states' constitutional family models.  
EFD dismisses the issue's premise as redundant, claiming existing societal respect for human dignity negates the need for targeted LGBTI policies.

GREEN_EFA strongly approves the issue's comprehensive approach to combating LGBTI discrimination, aligning perfectly with the party's longstanding commitment to intersectional equality and human rights.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on legal recognition of same-sex partnerships and gender-affirming healthcare access, which directly advances their manifesto priorities for bodily autonomy and family diversity.  
GREEN_EFA commends the focus on addressing intersectional discrimination against lesbians and ensuring safe educational environments for LGBTI youth, reflecting their systemic justice framework.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening the roadmap's mechanisms to explicitly condemn referendums on LGBTI rights, as highlighted in the debate, by adding binding language to prevent member states from subjecting fundamental rights to popular vote.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the critical need for EU-wide awareness campaigns and improved data collection, as outlined in the issue, to dismantle structural homophobia across all policy domains.

ALDE strongly upholds the adoption of a comprehensive EU roadmap against homophobia, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to safeguarding fundamental freedoms and combating discrimination in all forms.  
ALDE applauds the issue's focus on legal recognition of same-sex partnerships and parenthood, which effectively advances ALDE's priority of ensuring equal family rights across all Member States.  
ALDE endorses the urgent need to address workplace discrimination and violence against LGBTI individuals, particularly emphasizing the critical importance of improving police responsiveness to hate crimes as highlighted by low reporting rates.  
ALDE proposes enhancing awareness campaigns to explicitly counter conservative narratives seeking to roll back LGBTI rights, ensuring EU institutions lead by example in protecting vulnerable communities.  
ALDE emphasizes the necessity of binding measures against forced sterilization of intersex persons, urging swift implementation of gender recognition procedures that respect bodily autonomy.

SD strongly advocates the issue’s emphasis on equal rights for LGBTI individuals, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to combating systemic discrimination and ensuring no minority faces violence or exclusion in a civilized society.  
SD approves the urgent adoption of a multiannual EU roadmap, as demanded by Britta Thomsen, to coordinate anti-discrimination measures across employment, healthcare, and education, while proposing enhanced data collection to monitor member state compliance more effectively.  
SD endorses inclusive civic education initiatives, exemplified by Biljana Borzan’s reference to Croatia’s program, which aligns with SD’s priority of fostering societal acceptance through early intervention in schools and communities.  
SD strongly advocates legal recognition of same-sex partnerships and parenthood, ensuring family laws reflect modern European values and protect against intersectional discrimination faced by lesbian and transgender individuals.  
SD applauds the issue’s focus on combating hate speech, mirroring SD’s manifesto pledge to create safe public spaces and ensure LGBTI youth can thrive without fear of harassment or violence.

GUE_NGL strongly promotes the issue's condemnation of hate speech and violence against LGBTI individuals, aligning perfectly with GUE_NGL's longstanding commitment to intersectional equality and dignity for marginalized communities.  
GUE_NGL approves the demand for legal recognition of same-sex partnerships and parenthood, emphasizing its consistency with their manifesto principles of dismantling discriminatory family-law frameworks.  
GUE_NGL proposes strengthening measures against institutional censorship of anti-homophobia advocacy, referencing Ireland's RTE case as a critical enhancement opportunity for media accountability.  
GUE_NGL applauds the focus on intersectional discrimination faced by lesbians and transgender persons, noting its resonance with their 2023 priorities on healthcare access and gender self-determination.  
GUE_NGL underscores the urgency of addressing workplace discrimination through binding EU directives, mirroring their ongoing campaigns for labor rights expansion to LGBTQI+ workers.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over persistent discrimination and violence against LGBTI individuals in the EU, citing data from the 2013 EU LGBT survey revealing that 50% felt discriminated against or harassed, 33% faced discrimination accessing goods/services, 25% were physically attacked, and 20% experienced workplace discrimination. It condemned the lack of a comprehensive EU policy to protect LGBTI rights, despite repeated calls from Parliament and 11 Equality Ministers, and urged the Commission and Member States to adopt a multiannual roadmap addressing non-discrimination in employment, education, healthcare, goods/services, and specific challenges faced by transgender and intersex persons, including forced sterilization and inadequate legal recognition. The resolution emphasized ensuring access to gender reassignment services, legal recognition of same-sex partnerships and parenthood, inclusive family laws, non-discriminatory fertility treatments, and protection from hate speech and violence. It called for awareness campaigns, improved data collection, and mainstreaming LGBTI rights in EU policies, particularly in asylum, freedom of movement, and external relations, while stressing the need to address intersectional discrimination against lesbians and ensure media representation and safe educational environments for LGBTI youth.

title: Report: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra- Implementing rules for Europol analysis work files: REPORT on the draft Council decision adopting the implementing rules for Europol analysis work files
background: The imminent entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, altering EU legislative procedures for police cooperation, and a 2009 Council proposal to update Europol’s operational rules under the pre-Lisbon legal framework prompted institutional considerations. The Parliament will discuss adjustments to Europol’s analysis file protocols amid evolving governance structures for EU security agencies.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely againsts the interim amendments to Europol's rules as inconsistent with the Lisbon Treaty's imminent legal framework for police cooperation  
EPP rejects the Council's proposal, demanding withdrawal to prioritize post-Lisbon parliamentary involvement in shaping Europol's data governance  
EPP highlights the issue's contradiction with EPP's stance by attempting political data transfers outside Lisbon's legislative procedures  
EPP insists any Europol reforms must await December's treaty implementation to ensure victim rights and forensic standards align with enhanced parliamentary oversight  
EPP underscores the proposal's failure to address institutional balance, risking fragmented security markets without Lisbon-aligned interinstitutional coordination

EFD rejects the proposed Europol rules for permitting unchecked sharing of sensitive citizen data with third countries like Russia and Albania, fundamentally againsting with EFD’s commitment to safeguarding individual privacy and national sovereignty.  
EFD opposes granting Europol officers legal immunity, a concept inconsistent with British legal traditions and EFD’s principles of accountability and judicial oversight.  
EFD condemns the issue’s failure to address the erosion of national liberties through EU judicial instruments like the European arrest warrant, which undermines domestic legal protections.  
EFD highlights the proposal’s disregard for citizen consent, emphasizing that the Lisbon Treaty’s implementation without referenda contradicts EFD’s demand for democratic legitimacy in EU integration.  
EFD underscores the danger of prioritizing Europol’s operational interests over citizen rights, overlooking critical protections against unwarranted data collection and transnational surveillance.

GREEN_EFA rejects the interim amendments to Europol's analysis work files as fundamentally premature, conflicting with their insistence on full colegislative processes under the Lisbon Treaty.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the issue's failure to mandate explicit safeguards for decentralized forensic systems, exemplified by Spain's regional laboratories.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely disapproves with the proposal's centralized coordination model, which overlooks critical regional legal and police diversity within Member States.

ALDE totally disputes the interim amendments to Europol's rules as they disregard the imminent legal framework overhaul under the Lisbon Treaty, creating unacceptable legal uncertainty for citizens' rights.  
ALDE rejects piecemeal procedural changes that bypass Parliament's future colegislative role under Lisbon, demanding full alignment with enhanced parliamentary oversight mechanisms.  
The proposal conflicts with ALDE's insistence on Council accountability, as highlighted by multiple speakers condemning the Council's absence during critical debates on police cooperation reforms.  
ALDE condemns the failure to prioritize cross-border institutional coordination against trafficking and mafia networks, which Cecilia Wikström emphasized as requiring Lisbon-era tools for effective combat.  
 While supporting Europol's mission, ALDE insists any reform must wait for Lisbon's implementation to embed judicial safeguards and forensic data standardization raised by Alexander Alvaro.

SD rejects the Council's proposal to implement interim Europol rules, as it absolutely disputes with the imminent legal framework under the Lisbon Treaty requiring full parliamentary codecision.  
SD opposes the creation of unregulated data exchanges with unspecified third countries, citing Article 15(2)'s dangerous allowance of transmitting sensitive personal data under undefined "absolute necessity" clauses.  
SD demands withdrawal of current measures that bypass democratic scrutiny, asserting Parliament's right to fully exercise its strengthened legislative role post-Lisbon rather than accepting pre-emptive Council decisions.  
SD condemns the Council's procedural disregard evidenced by absent representatives during critical debates, undermining trustworthy inter-institutional cooperation required for effective police collaboration.  
SD challenges the proposal's failure to establish clear safeguards for handling racial, religious, and political data, noting the issue's inconsistency with fundamental EU principles of non-discrimination and data protection.

GUE_NGL rejects the interim amendments to Europol's implementing rules as entirely conflicting with their commitment to safeguarding fundamental rights like privacy and free movement.  
GUE_NGL opposes the rushed adoption process, highlighting the Council's failure to address democratic accountability by proceeding before Lisbon Treaty codecision powers take effect.  
GUE_NGL insists any Europol reforms must wait for the Lisbon Treaty framework to prevent security measures from undermining constitutional protections against coercive overreach.  
GUE_NGL condemns the proposal's disregard for legal coherence, as it overlooks critical aspects of balancing police cooperation with robust data confidentiality safeguards for EU citizens.  
GUE_NGL demands withdrawal of all pre-Lisbon Treaty Europol texts, asserting that piecemeal changes contradict their principle of prioritizing systemic justice over fragmented security policies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised objections to the proposed Council text amending the Europol Decision, rejecting it due to the imminent entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, which would alter the legal framework for police cooperation. It opposed making interim amendments to Europol’s implementing measures, arguing such changes should wait until the Lisbon Treaty’s provisions take effect. Parliament called on the Council to withdraw its current proposal and urged the Commission or Council to submit a new Europol decision proposal within six months of the Lisbon Treaty’s entry into force, ensuring alignment with the updated legal framework. Additionally, it instructed its President to communicate this position to the Council and Commission, emphasizing the need to prioritize coherence under the Lisbon Treaty over piecemeal reforms.

title: Motions for resolutions - Situation in Lithuania following the adoption of the law on protection of minors: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the Lithuanian Law on the Protection of Minors against the Detrimental Effects of Public Information
background: In July 2009, Lithuania adopted amendments to its Law on the Protection of Minors, prohibiting public information promoting homosexual, bisexual, or polygamous relations to minors. Following a presidential veto overruled by parliament, the law faced domestic review amid scrutiny under EU human rights frameworks. The Parliament will discuss the law’s compatibility with EU non-discrimination obligations and fundamental rights.

stances.stance:
EPP opposes fundamentally the issue's interference with national competence over family and social policy, as emphasized in the Lisbon Treaty's subsidiarity protocol.  
EPP rejects the assertion that Lithuania's law contravenes EU human rights obligations, citing Miroslav Mikolášik's analysis confirming alignment with international standards.  
EPP highlights the issue's contradiction with parental rights to shield children from sexualized content, per Anna Záborská's defense of national educational sovereignty.  
EPP condemns the premature condemnation of a law undergoing domestic review, noting Véronique Mathieu's trust in Lithuania's presidential working group.  
EPP disputes the Agency for Fundamental Rights' authority to assess national laws, aligning with Carlo Casini's institutional concerns about EU overreach.

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the issue’s condemnation of Lithuania’s law as discriminatory, aligning perfectly with their commitment to LGBTQ+ equality and opposition to state-sanctioned stigma.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing Article 4’s clarity to explicitly exclude artistic expression and public health discussions from restrictions, preventing misuse against queer communities.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the call for EU Fundamental Rights Agency oversight, effectively advancing their priority of binding human rights accountability across Member States.  
GREEN_EFA urges concrete timelines for Lithuania’s working group to revise the law, ensuring alignment with the Yogyakarta Principles on sexual orientation and gender identity.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the issue’s critical balance between child protection and fundamental freedoms, reflecting their manifesto stance against censorship disguised as safeguarding.

ALDE strongly sanctions the issue’s condemnation of Lithuania’s law for its discriminatory language and incompatibility with EU non-discrimination principles, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s commitment to LGBTQ+ rights and media freedom.  
ALDE applauds the emphasis on balancing child protection with fundamental freedoms, effectively advancing ALDE’s priority to combat state-sponsored homophobia while safeguarding democratic expression.  
ALDE endorses the call for Lithuania to revise Article 4’s vague provisions, proposing enhanced clarity to prevent abusive interpretations that conflate homosexuality with harm.  
ALDE welcomes the establishment of Lithuania’s working group but urges accelerated alignment with the Charter of Fundamental Rights, particularly regarding public information standards.  
ALDE emphasizes the urgency of the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights’ assessment, framing it as critical to upholding treaty obligations across all Member States.

SD strongly sanctions the issue’s alignment with EU anti-discrimination principles, particularly its emphasis on upholding Article 13 of the EC Treaty and the Charter of Fundamental Rights as foundational to protecting LGBTQ+ rights.  
SD applauds the call for Lithuania’s working group to rigorously align the law with international standards, proposing explicit inclusion of FRA guidelines to prevent ambiguous interpretations of "detrimental effects."  
SD endorses the issue’s demand for proactive EU monitoring, urging the Commission to initiate infringement procedures if discriminatory enforcement persists after March 2010.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of balancing child protection with artistic freedom, recommending clarifications in Article 4 to exempt educational materials and cultural expressions from overbroad restrictions.  
SD reaffirms the imperative to combat institutionalized homophobia, framing the issue as critical to advancing equality across all Member States in line with their 2009 equality agenda.

ECR totally doubts the issue's interference in national child protection policies, asserting this violates subsidiarity principles under Article 4(2) TEU.  
ECR rejects the characterization of Lithuania's law as discriminatory, emphasizing its alignment with parental rights to shape children's moral education.  
ECR contends the issue improperly conflates legitimate age-appropriate content regulation with LGBTQ+ discrimination, contrary to ECR's sovereignty-first agenda.  
ECR argues the issue overlooks critical distinctions between restricting harmful content and suppressing identities, a core flaw in its legal analysis.  
ECR opposes EU institutions' role in redefining "detrimental effects" on minors, which remains firmly within national competence under EU treaties.

GUE_NGL strongly endorses the issue’s condemnation of Lithuania’s discriminatory law, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to LGBTQ+ equality and universal human rights.  
GUE_NGL applauds the emphasis on EU fundamental rights frameworks, effectively advancing their priority of combating systemic discrimination through supranational legal accountability.  
GUE_NGL proposes enhancing the working group’s mandate by requiring explicit consultation with LGBTQ+ civil society to ensure inclusive compliance with anti-discrimination standards.  
GUE_NGL underscores the issue’s critical alignment with child protection principles that reject stigmatization, affirming that safeguarding minors must never legitimize censorship or inequality.  
GUE_NGL welcomes the unified institutional stance across Parliament, Commission, and Council as vital to upholding shared EU values against regressive national legislation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding Lithuania’s Law on the Protection of Minors, amended in July 2009 to prohibit promoting homosexual, bisexual, or polygamous relations to minors, set to take effect on 1 March 2010, citing potential harm to minors. It criticized the law’s vague wording, particularly Article 4, for risking discriminatory interpretations and conflicting with EU and international human rights obligations, including non-discrimination principles under Article 13 of the EC Treaty and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The resolution highlighted the law’s ambiguity over its scope, including potential restrictions on media, art, and public events, and noted ongoing reviews by Lithuanian authorities following the President’s veto overruling. It welcomed Lithuania’s establishment of a working group to align the law with EU and international standards, urged compliance with human rights frameworks, and called on the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights to assess the law’s conformity with EU treaties. The Parliament reaffirmed commitments to combat discrimination based on sexual orientation, uphold child protection principles, and monitor developments, stressing the need to balance minors’ protection with fundamental freedoms and equality.

title: Movement of persons with a long-stay visa: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Convention Implementing the Schengen Agreement and Regulation (EC) No 562/2006 as regards movement of persons with a long-stay visa
background: The Schengen Convention restricted long-stay visa holders to the issuing Member State, with inconsistent national practices delaying residence permits. The 2010 Visa Code's abolition of D+C visas risked further mobility barriers. The Parliament will discuss aligning long-stay visa holders' movement rights with residence permit holders under Schengen rules.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the harmonization of long-stay visa rights with residence permits to eliminate barriers for third-country nationals legally residing in the EU, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to pragmatic freedom of movement.  
EPP approves the issue’s focus on academic and professional mobility, emphasizing its potential to transform the Schengen area into a cohesive space for research and education without bureaucratic impediments.  
EPP highlights the mandatory integration of Schengen Information System checks as a critical enhancement opportunity to balance free movement with robust security protocols, ensuring trust in border management.  
EPP advocates for standardized visa issuance procedures across Member States to prevent regulatory loopholes, proposing strengthened intergovernmental coordination to maintain Schengen integrity.  
EPP applauds the issue’s symbolic significance in advancing EU values of openness, particularly for neighboring communities and students, effectively advancing EPP’s priority of fostering cross-border cultural exchange.

EFD rejects the proposal's equivalence between long-stay visas and residence permits, completely againsting with EFD's insistence on strict national border sovereignty.  
EFD opposes extending Schengen mobility to long-stay visa holders, overlooking critical security vulnerabilities in cross-border immigration enforcement.  
EFD condemns the issue's facilitation of third-country nationals' movement, which directly undermines efforts to combat illegal entry via secondary EU states.  
EFD highlights the proposal's failure to address chain migration risks, inconsistent with EFD's demand for absolute control over territorial access points.  
EFD warns this measure would erode Member States' capacity to track overstays, contradicting core principles of immigration restriction and border integrity.

ALDE completely approves the issue's advancement of freedom of movement for third-country nationals, perfectly aligning with their commitment to a borderless Europe that prioritizes secure mobility and integration.  
ALDE applauds the elimination of territorial restrictions for legal residents, effectively advancing their vision of a unified Schengen Area that fosters cultural exchange and academic collaboration.  
ALDE highlights the issue’s alignment with Treaty principles on legal migration, reinforcing their longstanding advocacy for coherent EU-wide policies that transcend national barriers.  
ALDE emphasizes the strategic importance of framing Europe as a single entity to third-country nationals, consistent with their mission to strengthen the EU’s global identity and attractiveness.  
ALDE commends the issue for resolving procedural discontinuities under the Lisbon Treaty, ensuring legal clarity in cross-border rights for students, researchers, and long-term visa holders.

SD strongly endorses harmonizing long-stay visa mobility with residence permit privileges, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to dismantling barriers for legally present third-country nationals engaged in work or study.  
SD approves the three-month mobility provision but proposes reinforcing Member State coordination through shared best practices on permit issuance efficiency to prevent prolonged visa-residence gaps.  
SD highlights the critical need to operationalize SIS II by 2012 as a security enhancement opportunity, urging contingency measures to replicate its data protection standards if delayed.  
SD advocates extending free movement rights to business professionals under the regulation, noting this would advance EU competitiveness while maintaining rigorous border control protocols.  
SD emphasizes aligning this reform with accelerated visa liberalization for Western Balkan states, ensuring coherence with broader EU integration priorities and mitigating regional isolation risks.

ECR partly sanctions the alignment of long-stay visa mobility with short-term visa holders but requests mandatory Schengen Information System integration to track security risks.  
ECR insists on amendments requiring Member States to share real-time data on "undesirable persons" through Article 5 revisions, arguing current provisions lack enforcement mechanisms.  
ECR demands the Commission produce an implementation report by April 2012, noting the issue’s oversight of accountability timelines.  
ECR questions the legal coherence under Article 77(2)(b) without explicit safeguards against cross-border criminal exploitation, creating potential security gaps.  
ECR supports procedural continuity post-Lisbon Treaty but warns against diluting national sovereignty in border policy oversight.

GUE_NGL strongly advocates the issue’s advancement of freedom of movement for third-country nationals, aligning perfectly with their commitment to dismantling border barriers and fostering inclusive mobility.  
GUE_NGL applauds the rapporteur’s collaborative approach, which effectively advances their priority of safeguarding migrants’ rights and strengthening cross-border scientific and academic exchanges.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the urgency of preempting the Visa Code’s restrictive impacts, proposing accelerated implementation to prevent disruptions to researchers’ mobility.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s alignment with equitable labor practices, noting enhanced workforce mobility as critical to addressing economic and knowledge-sector challenges.  
GUE_NGL underscores the necessity of this reform for upholding the EU’s global competitiveness in attracting and retaining skilled non-EU professionals.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position by adopting the first reading on a legislative proposal concerning freedom of movement and immigration, incorporating the contents of Commission proposal COM(2009)0090 and related draft reports into procedure 2009/0028 (COD), thereby declaring procedure 2009/0025 (COD) lapsed. It emphasized alignment with the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, particularly Articles 77(2)(b) and (c) and 79(2)(a), to ensure legal coherence in policies on border controls and legal migration. The resolution urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal if intending significant amendments or replacements and directed its President to transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural continuity under the post-Lisbon Treaty framework.

title: Protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data (General Data Protection Regulation)
background: Rapid digitalization, globalization of data flows, and fragmented national implementations of the 1995 EU Data Protection Directive highlighted the need to modernize privacy frameworks. The Lisbon Treaty empowered EU institutions to strengthen fundamental rights protections in cross-border contexts. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing data protection rules to address technological advancements and ensure consistent application across member states.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the harmonization of data protection rules across the EU, aligning perfectly with their commitment to eliminating fragmentation and creating a competitive Digital Single Market through the one-stop-shop mechanism.  
EPP approves enhanced safeguards for minors, particularly child-friendly information formats and strict consent requirements, effectively advancing their priority of protecting vulnerable groups in digital environments.  
EPP emphasizes balancing robust privacy protections with innovation, endorsing technologically neutral provisions that enable SME growth while preventing data misuse, in line with manifesto goals for economic progress.  
EPP proposes amending Article 9 to refine sensitive data definitions with exceptions for medical research and public health registries, ensuring compatibility with national healthcare systems without opposing core principles.  
EPP urges maintaining legislative coherence by advancing both the regulation and accompanying law enforcement directive to ensure comprehensive fundamental rights protection across all data domains.

GREEN_EFA firmly endorses the issue's prohibition on personal data transfers to third countries, perfectly aligning with their commitment to digital sovereignty and fundamental rights against extraterritorial surveillance.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the urgency to finalize robust protections against U.S. tech giants like Google and Facebook, advancing their manifesto goal of reclaiming citizen control over corporate data exploitation.  
GREEN_EFA firmly endorses empowering European companies to become global leaders in secure data processing, reflecting their vision for ethical technological innovation under the GDPR framework.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with mandating explicit consent and "right to be forgotten" provisions, effectively advancing their decades-long advocacy against mass data retention in SWIFT and PNR agreements.  
GREEN_EFA firmly endorses simplifying privacy terms through standardized symbols, a policy innovation directly mirroring their 2014 campaign to reduce bureaucratic burdens while enhancing transparency.

ALDE strongly accepts the GDPR proposal’s harmonization of data protection rules across Europe, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s commitment to balancing robust privacy rights with innovation-friendly frameworks for digital economy growth.  
ALDE applauds the emphasis on strict enforcement mechanisms and sanctions, which effectively advance trust between citizens and businesses by ensuring compliance and fair competition.  
ALDE proposes strengthening safeguards for health data processing by mandating explicit consent protocols and transparent opt-out systems to prevent trust erosion, as exemplified by the UK’s mismanaged Care.data initiative.  
ALDE strongly endorses the reinstatement of the anti-Pfizer clause to protect EU citizens from third-country court orders, a critical measure for upholding jurisdictional sovereignty over personal data.  
ALDE emphasizes the need for predictable and well-structured data governance in medical research to maintain public confidence, urging enhanced oversight frameworks to prevent procedural failures like those seen in NHS England’s implementation.

SD strongly sanctions the inclusion of explicit consent requirements and the "right to be forgotten" as pivotal advancements in fundamental digital rights protection, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to citizen sovereignty over personal data.  
SD applauds the harmonized framework for cross-border data transfers under solid legal bases like international treaties, effectively advancing EU citizens' privacy against extraterritorial surveillance abuses.  
SD proposes enhancing pseudonymization standards by classifying such processed data under personal data protections to close potential loopholes, while maintaining full support for the regulation's core principles.  
SD endorses the 72-hour breach notification mandate and joint liability clauses for data processors as critical accountability mechanisms, reflecting SD's 2023 priorities on corporate transparency.  
SD urges expedited revision of existing EU-third country data agreements (e.g., SWIFT) to ensure coherence with the new regulation, framing this as a necessary technical alignment rather than substantive opposition.

ECR strongly approves the harmonization of data protection rules across Member States as a vital step toward completing the Digital Single Market, aligning with ECR's commitment to reducing regulatory fragmentation and fostering cross-border innovation.  
ECR proposes amending Articles 81 and 83 to include tailored exemptions for large-scale medical research projects, ensuring compliance with data protection principles while enabling critical advancements in treating diseases like cancer and Alzheimer’s.  
ECR approves the issue’s emphasis on proportionality, particularly its recognition that administrative burdens on SMEs must be minimized to avoid stifling economic growth and technological development.  
ECR urges enhancing Article 6 to clarify lawful grounds for processing sensitive data in security contexts, ensuring law enforcement agencies can effectively investigate terrorism and war crimes without compromising fundamental rights.  
ECR applauds the issue’s focus on preventing non-EU entities from accessing personal data without equivalent safeguards, reinforcing ECR’s manifesto priority of protecting EU citizens from extraterritorial surveillance overreach.

GUE_NGL strongly promotes the issue's foundation in treating data protection as a fundamental right essential for personal autonomy and democratic participation, aligning perfectly with their commitment to safeguarding civil liberties against corporate and state surveillance.  
GUE_NGL applauds the modernized data protection framework for proactively addressing digital-era challenges, mirroring their manifesto priorities to prevent individuals from becoming "transparent objects of observation."  
GUE_NGL proposes reinforcing accountability mechanisms for the Council to prevent procedural delays, ensuring swift implementation without opposing the regulation's core principles.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes that robust privacy safeguards directly enable citizens' political agency, a principle central to their advocacy against exploitative data commodification.  
GUE_NGL approves the issue's harmonized approach as critical to preventing regulatory fragmentation that could weaken protections across member states, consistent with their transnational solidarity ethos.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s 2012 legislative proposal (COM(2012)0011) on harmonizing rules under Articles 16(2) and 114(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, emphasizing the need to address subsidiarity objections from five national parliaments (Belgium, Germany, France, Italy, Sweden) that argued the proposal overstepped EU competence. It integrated opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee, the European Data Protection Supervisor, and the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights, stressing the importance of data protection and fundamental rights compliance. The Parliament adopted its position, urging the Commission to reassess the proposal’s alignment with subsidiarity principles and to resubmit it if substantial revisions were made, while instructing its President to transmit the resolution to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure transparency and adherence to legislative protocols.

title: Public access to European Parliament, Council and Commission documents: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council regarding public access to European Parliament, Council and Commission documents (recast)
background: The 2001 EU regulation on public access to documents required revision following the 2009 Lisbon Treaty's expanded transparency obligations. The European Commission proposed amendments in 2008 and 2011 to align rules with treaty provisions and extend coverage to all EU institutions. The Parliament will discuss revising public document access regulations to implement treaty requirements and broaden institutional transparency.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the proposed regulation's overbroad document definition that exposes sensitive legislative negotiations and strategic security discussions to undue external influence  
EPP opposes fundamentally the mandatory publication of trialogue minutes as it undermines confidential negotiation spaces vital for effective EU lawmaking  
EPP condemns the failure to protect business confidentiality and operational security of agencies like Europol through inadequate exceptions in Articles 4-6  
EPP disputes the issue's contradiction with existing data protection frameworks by prioritizing disclosure over privacy safeguards in Recital 18  
EPP warns that unlimited access to preparatory documents creates lobbyist vulnerabilities inconsistent with institutional integrity commitments

EFD partly sanctions the transparency framework but requests revisions to Article 15 provisions, arguing the issue risks overreach by mandating publication of documents "unsuitable for dissemination" without adequate institutional safeguards.  
EFD objects to extending public control mechanisms beyond the Commission’s original recast proposal (COM(2008)0229), citing contradictions with procedural efficiency goals in Treaty Article 294(3).  
EFD urges stricter alignment with the minority opinion under Rule 52(3) to delete amendments that "go beyond necessary frameworks," particularly regarding third-party document disclosures in Cashman’s report.  
EFD emphasizes the need to maintain exemptions for sensitive legislative deliberations, warning that unqualified access could provoke "counter-productive disputes" undermining EU decision-making.  
EFD calls for explicit recognition of member states’ rights under Article 42 to veto document releases affecting national security interests.

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the issue’s emphasis on institutional transparency, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to democratic accountability and citizen oversight in EU decision-making.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the integration of Article 15 TFEU principles, effectively advancing their priority of ensuring public access to documents as a safeguard against opaque lobbying influences.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing judicial review mechanisms for confidentiality claims to ensure exceptions are rigorously justified, reinforcing the issue’s alignment with rule-of-law standards.  
GREEN_EFA underscores the critical need for procedural clarity in document classification, urging stricter criteria for exceptions to prevent undue secrecy while maintaining operational efficiency.  
GREEN_EFA reaffirms the issue’s role in combating euroscepticism through transparency, as highlighted in their 2023 manifesto demanding open governance to rebuild public trust.

ALDE strongly endorses the issue's emphasis on financial transparency and public access to EU fund beneficiaries as critical to combating corruption, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to institutional accountability.  
ALDE approves the provisions limiting Member States' veto power over document publication, which directly advances ALDE's priority of curbing opaque decision-making in legislative processes.  
ALDE proposes enhancing Article 4 to mandate real-time updates of the expenditure database, ensuring citizens can monitor fund allocation without procedural delays.  
ALDE applauds the report's rejection of broad exceptions to document access in legislative matters, a stance matching their 2023 manifesto pledge for unqualified transparency in law-making.  
ALDE underscores the necessity of applying electronic document access rules uniformly across all EU agencies, reinforcing the issue's alignment with Treaty obligations under Article 15 TFEU.

SD strongly upholds the issue’s transparency framework, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to open governance and citizen empowerment under the Charter of Fundamental Rights.  
SD proposes amending Article 3 to expand the definition of ‘document’ to include official information, enabling precise requests, partial access to classified materials, and reducing administrative burdens while upholding EU jurisprudence.  
SD applauds the rejection of Member States’ unconditional veto over document access, ensuring institutional accountability and compliance with European Court of Justice rulings.  
SD underscores the necessity of prohibiting financial barriers to information access, urging fee-free requests in line with the Aarhus Convention to prevent exclusionary practices.  
SD endorses strict classification criteria to prevent over-classification of documents, reinforcing transparency as essential to rebuilding public trust in EU institutions.

GUE_NGL strongly approves the issue’s rejection of the Commission’s limitations on document access, aligning perfectly with GUE_NGL’s commitment to radical transparency in EU decision-making.  
GUE_NGL applauds the prioritization of citizen engagement during Council negotiation phases, effectively advancing their principle that democratic legitimacy requires real-time public scrutiny.  
GUE_NGL proposes explicitly mandating proactive publication of draft compromise texts in Council working groups to preempt procedural opacity, enhancing the issue’s intent.  
GUE_NGL underscores the critical need to resist institutional attempts to classify negotiation documents, as secrecy disproportionately empowers corporate interests over public participation.  
GUE_NGL affirms that the issue’s alignment with Article 42 of the Charter reflects their longstanding demand for transparency as a non-negotiable democratic safeguard.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the codification of legislative procedures, emphasizing that the Commission’s proposal (COM(2008)0229) incorporated into procedure 2008/0090(COD) did not introduce substantive amendments beyond those explicitly identified, as confirmed by the Consultative Working Party of the legal services. It noted that procedure 2011/0073(COD) had lapsed due to the integration of the Commission’s subsequent proposal (COM(2011)0137) into the earlier procedure, ensuring continuity. The resolution called on the Commission to re-engage Parliament if future proposals substantially alter or replace the current text, underscoring adherence to transparency and institutional cooperation under Articles 41 and 42 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. It instructed its President to transmit Parliament’s position to the Council and Commission, reaffirming the need for procedural clarity and alignment with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (Article 294(3) and Article 15) while maintaining the unchanged substance of codified legal acts.

title: Qualification and status of third country nationals or stateless persons as beneficiaries of international protection: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on minimum standards for the qualification and status of third country nationals or stateless persons as beneficiaries of international protection and the content of the protection granted (recast)
background: Persistent disparities in EU Member States' asylum qualification criteria and protection standards, alongside evolving international refugee law and the 2012 deadline for a Common European Asylum System, prompted legislative review. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing minimum standards for recognizing third-country nationals' eligibility for international protection under EU law.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates maintaining the distinction between asylum and subsidiary protection statuses, ensuring differentiated residence permit durations to deter procedural abuse while upholding protection obligations. This aligns with EPP's commitment to system integrity and fair burden-sharing across Member States.  

EPP approves the precise definition of family members in eligibility assessments, preventing exploitation of reunification provisions while safeguarding minors’ welfare through mandatory best-interest evaluations. This advances EPP’s child protection priorities within asylum frameworks.  

EPP endorses explicit recognition of persecution via harmful traditional practices (e.g., forced sterilisation) as a critical expansion of protection criteria, reflecting EPP’s human rights agenda and gender-sensitive policy alignment.  

EPP highlights the necessity of harmonised standards for subsidiary protection eligibility, particularly exclusion clauses for serious criminality, to balance humanitarian obligations with Member States’ security imperatives.  

EPP proposes reinforcing references to internal relocation alternatives within origin countries during subsidiary protection assessments, ensuring nuanced application without undermining core protection principles. This minor procedural enhancement optimizes directive implementation.

EFD rejects the issue's failure to address Dublin Regulation reforms critical for relieving border states like Greece from disproportionate migration burdens.  
EFD opposes centralized asylum policy unification as fully doubting with national sovereignty principles in migration management.  
EFD fully doubts with the proposal's technical codification approach that overlooks immediate operational crises at EU external borders.  
EFD rejects the issue's disregard for practical implementation challenges faced by national institutions with asylum processing expertise.  
EFD opposes the lack of enforceable burden-sharing mechanisms, perpetuating unsustainable pressure on frontline Member States.

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the codification of asylum standards as a crucial step toward a unified European protection system, aligning perfectly with their commitment to refugee rights.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s technical clarity, which effectively advances transparency in asylum procedures without diluting existing protections.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing future directives to explicitly mandate binding solidarity mechanisms among Member States, ensuring equitable responsibility-sharing.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the urgency of complementary measures for refugee integration, urging swift action on post-qualification support frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the issue’s adherence to Article 78 TFEU as foundational for building a humane and coordinated asylum policy.

ALDE strongly agrees the codification of the Qualification Directive as a vital step toward realizing a unified European asylum system by 2012, aligning with their commitment to solidarity and equitable responsibility-sharing among Member States.  
ALDE applauds the explicit inclusion of gender identity and sexual orientation as grounds for persecution, advancing protections for marginalized groups in line with progressive humanitarian values.  
ALDE welcomes the compromise on correlation tables, proposing enhanced clarity in Member States’ implementation reporting to ensure consistent application of asylum standards across the EU.  
ALDE highlights the strengthened safeguards for unaccompanied minors as a critical advancement, reflecting their prioritization of vulnerable populations in international protection frameworks.  
ALDE urges accelerated progress on harmonizing refugee and subsidiary protection statuses, particularly addressing residual disparities in residence permits and social benefits to achieve full equality.

ECR rejects the codification approach as totally conflicting with their principle of national sovereignty in asylum policy.  
ECR opposes mandatory EU standards that limit Member States' ability to maintain more favourable asylum provisions than those in Articles 4-7.  
ECR condemns the expanded family member definition under Section 2(c) as inconsistent with their strict immigration control priorities.  
ECR argues the narrow refusal grounds for refugee status in Article 15(3) overlook critical security vetting requirements.  
ECR fundamentally disputes the legal basis under TFEU Article 78(2)(b), viewing responsibility-sharing mechanisms as compulsion rather than voluntary coordination.

GUE_NGL rejects the Qualification Directive's failure to establish uniform social security rights for refugees as fundamentally againsting with their demand for equitable treatment across all protection statuses.  
GUE_NGL opposes the fragmented legislative approach to asylum policy, highlighting how piecemeal adoption of directives overlooks critical solidarity mechanisms needed to relieve pressure on southern EU border states.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's tolerance of divergent national practices in child protection cases as inconsistent with their absolute commitment to standardized safeguards for unaccompanied minors.  
GUE_NGL fundamentally againsts with the directive's procedural decoupling from broader asylum reforms, warning this enables member states to indefinitely delay binding responsibility-sharing agreements.  
GUE_NGL rejects the artificial separation of qualification standards from reception conditions, arguing this perpetuates a two-tier system that undermines social integration guarantees central to their platform.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning the codification of existing legal texts related to freedom of movement and asylum under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). The resolution confirmed that the proposal, based on a Commission communication and aligned with the Consultative Working Party’s assessment, did not introduce substantive amendments but instead consolidated unchanged provisions from prior acts into a single codified text. It emphasized adherence to legal bases under Article 78(2)(a) and (b) TFEU, which govern common asylum procedures and fair sharing of responsibility among member states. Parliament endorsed the codification process as a technical exercise to enhance clarity and transparency without altering the legal substance of existing rules. It instructed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, underscoring compliance with interinstitutional agreements on legislative recasting and procedural coherence.

title: Surveillance of external sea borders: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing rules for the surveillance of the external sea borders in the context of operational cooperation coordinated by the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union
background: Increased migratory pressure from North Africa post-Arab Spring, recurring maritime tragedies in the Mediterranean, and divergent national border surveillance practices prompted EU institutional action following a Court of Justice ruling annulling prior guidelines. The Parliament will discuss establishing standardized EU rules for external sea border surveillance operations coordinated by Frontex.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the regulation’s operational focus on search-and-rescue obligations, aligning perfectly with EPP’s longstanding commitment to human dignity and maritime safety.  
EPP proposes amending Article 3 to specify increased Frontex operational funding allocations, ensuring parity with frontline states’ expenditures like Italy’s €110 million border management costs.  
EPP applauds the solidarity mechanism for northern member states’ participation, which effectively advances EPP’s priority of shared responsibility in migration governance.  
EPP emphasizes enhancing partnerships with transit countries such as Morocco and Tunisia, framing this as an enhancement opportunity to preemptively address migratory root causes.  
EPP endorses integrating regional reception frameworks under UNHCR principles into the regulation’s preamble to strengthen preventive measures against human trafficking.

GREEN_EFA rejects the regulation's failure to implement mandatory individual asylum assessments as required by the European Court of Human Rights' Hirsi judgment, completely condemning with their principle of non-refoulement.  
GREEN_EFA opposes disembarkation protocols allowing returns to third countries like Libya, overlooking critical aspects of North African states' non-compliance with Geneva Convention protections.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the absence of onboard legal interpreters and appeal mechanisms during maritime operations, inconsistent with their demand for real-time refugee rights safeguards.  
GREEN_EFA disputes the claim that push-backs are fully prohibited, noting loopholes permitting indirect returns through "cooperation" with unsafe third countries.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the reliance on radio-based assessments as a violation of human rights due process standards, failing to address the Court's requirement for face-to-case evaluations.

ALDE strongly advocates the binding rules for maritime search and rescue operations, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to human rights and refugee protection in border management.  
ALDE approves the explicit prohibition of push-back maneuvers on international waters as a critical safeguard against rights violations, effectively advancing ALDE's priority of upholding non-refoulement principles.  
ALDE applauds the mandatory identification protocols and special protections for asylum seekers, which directly address vulnerabilities exploited by human traffickers.  
ALDE proposes enhancing implementation by urging member states to mirror these standards in national operations, ensuring uniform compliance across all maritime zones.  
ALDE commends the reinforced solidarity mechanisms between EU states, which operationalize shared responsibility in managing migration flows while combating smuggling networks.

SD strongly advocates the expanded mandate for maritime search and rescue operations, which aligns perfectly with SD's commitment to prioritizing human life over border enforcement.  
SD approves the explicit prohibition of pushbacks and non-refoulement guarantees as critical advancements in upholding international human rights standards at sea.  
SD endorses reinforced parliamentary oversight of Frontex operations, ensuring accountability through mandatory reporting on compliance with the European Convention on Human Rights.  
SD proposes enhancing provisions for safe legal migration pathways in future legislation to complement border measures, addressing root causes through coordinated EU development and trade policies.
